headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2015 Hess Corporation Conference Call. My name is Candice, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2015 Hess Corporation Conference Call. My name is Candice, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Jay Wilson, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in our Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Our earnings release was issued in this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projections and
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in our Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Our earnings release was issued in this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. 
Today's conference call contains projections and other forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. These statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from those expressed or implied in such statements. These risks include those set forth in the risk factors section of Hess' annual and quarterly reports filed with the SEC.
Also on today's conference call, we may discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation of the differences between these non-GAAP financial measures and those most directly comparable GAAP financial measures can be found in the supplemental information provided on our website. 
With me today are John Hess, Chief Executive Officer; Greg Hill, Chief Operating Officer; and John Rielly, Chief Financial Officer. I will now turn the call over to John Hess.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay. Welcome to our fourth quarter conference call. I will provide an update on the steps we are taking in response to the low oil price environment and will review highlights from 2015. Greg Hill will then discuss our operating performance. An
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay. Welcome to our fourth quarter conference call. I will provide an update on the steps we are taking in response to the low oil price environment and will review highlights from 2015. Greg Hill will then discuss our operating performance. And John Rielly will review our financial results. 
Three principles are guiding us through this lower-for-longer oil price environment: Preserve the strength of our balance sheet, preserve our operating capabilities and preserve our long-term growth options. By adhering to this disciplined approach, we finished the year with one of the strongest balance sheets and liquidity positions among our E&P peers, with $2.7 billion of cash and undrawn $4 billion revolving credit facility that goes out to January 2020 and a net debt to capitalization ratio excluding the Bakken midstream joint venture of approximately 15%.
Our top priority in this challenging environment is to continue to keep our balance sheet strong. Yesterday, we announced a 2016 capital and exploratory budget of $2.4 billion, 40% below our 2015 spend and approximately 20% below the preliminary guidance we provided in late October of $2.9 billion to $3.1 billion. Our focus is on value, not volume, and we do not think it makes sense to accelerate production in the current price environment, particularly given the recent further deterioration in the oil markets. For this reason, we will reduce activity levels across our producing portfolio in 2016, both onshore and offshore, and will continue to pursue further cost reductions to preserve the strength of our balance sheet.
Our 2016 production forecast remains the same as our previous guidance of 330,000 to 350,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, even with the roughly $600 million of additional cuts in capital spend from our previous guidance and the recent sale of our assets in Algeria in December, which contributed net production of 10,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the fourth quarter of 2015.
In terms of our year-end reserves, as a result of a significant price-driven negative revision and a corresponding reduction in activity levels, our proved reserves decreased year-over-year to 1.086 billion barrels of oil equivalent at year-end 2015. It is important to note that all of the decrease was in proved undeveloped category and that our proved developed producing reserves increased by approximately 4% versus 2014.
Now turning to our 2015 financial results. Our adjusted net loss was $1.1 billion, and cash flow from operations before changes in working capital was $1.9 billion. Compared to 2014, our results were positively impacted by higher crude oil and natural gas sales volumes, which were more than offset by lower crude oil and natural gas selling prices and higher DD&A expense. 
From an operational standpoint, 2015 was a year of outstanding performance with strong execution across the portfolio and we are very proud of the work our team has done in a difficult oil price environment. Actual production was 375,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day versus our October guidance of 370,000 to 375,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. On a pro forma basis, excluding Libya and asset sales, 2015 production increased by 18% compared to 2014, averaging 368,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day versus 311,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day the prior year on the same basis. 
Also, during 2015, we delivered significant reductions in both capital expenditures and cash operating costs and achieved early success with our focused exploration program.
Turning to the Bakken. Hess has an industry-leading acreage position that is competitive with the best shale oil plays in the United States. Through the application of lean manufacturing techniques, our Bakken team has continued to drill some of the lowest cost and most productive wells in the play. Our 2016 focus is on the core of the core where Hess has significantly more drilling spacing units or DSUs than any other competitor. Maintaining a 2-rig program will help preserve our top quartile operating capabilities so that we are positioned to efficiently increase activity when oil prices recover. Bakken production in 2015 averaged 112,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up approximately 35% from 2014. Despite dropping to 2 rigs, we continue to forecast Bakken production to average between 95,000 and 105,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2016. 
On July 1, 2015, we closed on the Bakken Midstream joint venture, which resulted in total cash proceeds to Hess of $3 billion. Hess maintains operational control of these strategic assets, giving us access to the best markets for our products through the flexibility that it offers. As previously announced, the joint venture plans to proceed with an initial public offering of Hess Midstream Partners LP common units when market conditions improve. 
In terms of developments, while we are significantly reducing investment across our base portfolio, we plan to continue to invest for future growth with 2 offshore developments. The first in North Malay Basin is a long life, low risk natural gas resource with Oil Enterprises. Hess is operator with a 50% interest. Full field development is on track for startup in 2017 after which the project is expected to add an incremental 20,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day of production and become a long-term cash generator. 
Our second offshore development, Stampede, is one of the largest undeveloped fields in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, with estimated gross recoverable resources of between 300 million and 350 million barrels of oil equivalent. Hess is the operator of Stampede and we have a 25% interest. Following startup in 2018, the project will add an incremental 15,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day of production and become a material cash generator.
Turning to explorations. We are very pleased with the early results from our focused exploration program namely, the Exxon-operated Liza discovery offshore Guyana in which Hess has a 30% working interest and the Chevron-operated Sicily discovery in the deep water Gulf of Mexico in which Hess has a 25% working interest. In particular, we believe that the Stabroek Block in Guyana has the potential to be very material to Hess and create significant long-term value for our shareholders even in a lower price environment. About 90% of a 17,000 square kilometer 3D seismic acquisition program has been completed. In 2016, we plan to drill up to 4 wells to evaluate the Liza discovery, perform a drill stem test and explore additional prospects on the block.
In summary, we are well-positioned to navigate this lower-for-longer price environment and are taking a disciplined approach to: Preserve our financial strength, competitively advantage capabilities and long-term growth options. I will now turn the call over to Greg for an operational update.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I would like to provide an operational update on our progress in 2015 and our plans for 2016. As John mentioned, 2015 was a year of strong execution across our portfolio. Production averaged 375,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day at the
componenttext:
Thanks, John. I would like to provide an operational update on our progress in 2015 and our plans for 2016. 
As John mentioned, 2015 was a year of strong execution across our portfolio. Production averaged 375,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day at the top end of our October guidance of 370,000 to 375,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Furthermore, in the fourth quarter, production averaged 368,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, exceeding our October guidance of 360,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day for the same quarter. 
In 2015, we also reduced capital and exploratory expenditures by $400 million during the year and cash operating cost by more than $300 million. We continue to drive down our drilling and completion costs and successfully conducted tighter spacing and increased stage count pilots in the Bakken. We also achieved material exploration success in Guyana and the deepwater Gulf of Mexico where the Liza and Sicily wells were ranked as the 2 largest oil discoveries of 2015 by both Wood Mackenzie and IHS. 
Clearly, 2015 was a challenging year in terms of oil prices, and we believe it is prudent to manage the business, assuming that prices remain lower for longer. On that basis, we announced yesterday a 2016 capital and exploratory budget of $2.4 billion, which is 40% below 2015 levels and will result in significant reductions in activity levels across our unconventionals and offshore business.
Year-end 2015 proved reserves were significantly impacted by the price environment, with the addition of 84 million barrels of oil equivalent offset by price-related downward revisions of 282 million barrels of oil equivalent. Year-end proved reserves accounting for the sale of our Algeria asset were 1.086 billion barrels of oil equivalent, of which 73% were proved developed. Nonetheless, the notable early success of our exploration program and continued technical advances in our unconventionals business have allowed us to materially grow our total resource base. 
In 2016, we forecast companywide production to average between 330,000 and 350,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. This forecast is unchanged from preliminary guidance provided on our last quarterly conference call despite the further 20% reduction in our capital and exploratory expenditures. In the first quarter of 2016, we forecast companywide production to average between 340,000 and 350,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day.
Turning to operations. The Bakken continues to deliver outstanding performance as well as higher upside. We exceeded our production targets; continued to substantially reduce our well cost through the continued application of lean manufacturing techniques; significantly improved our well IP rates through the successful testing of 50 stage sliding sleeve fracs, an industry first in the Bakken; and increased our well inventory and estimated open recovery through infilling to tighter spacing using a 9/8 configuration. Full year production in the Bakken averaged 112,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which was 35% above 2014 and above our guidance from the beginning of the year of 95,000 to 105,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
In the fourth quarter, as a result of lower drilling activity, net production averaged 109,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up 7% from the year-ago quarter. Lean manufacturing practices enabled us to once again significantly drive down our Bakken drilling and completion costs, with the fourth quarter averaging $5.1 million per well versus $7.1 million per well in the year-ago quarter, a reduction of 28%. Looking forward, we expect drilling and completion costs in 2016 to remain near this level even though we will increase stage counts by approximately 40% as we move from our standard 35-stage design to a 50-stage design. The 50-stage trials conducted in 2015 had been very successful, delivering more than a 20% average increase in IP 30, 60 and 90. Our tighter well spacing pilots in 2015 have also been successful. Results to date confirm that moving from 13 wells to 17 wells per DSU is value accretive in the core of the play, enabling us to add 200 new drilling locations to our inventory. Additional pilots will be required in the future to fully understand the applicability across all of our acreage, which, to some degree, will be a function of price. 
The combination of our successful infill pilot and overall stronger type curve performance has allowed us to increase our estimated ultimate recovery from the Bakken to $1.6 billion barrels of oil equivalent from our previous estimate of 1.4 billion barrels of oil equivalent. 
Our industry-leading Bakken position continues to provide a forward well inventory that has one of the lowest breakevens in the play. However, in the current pricing environment, we believe it is prudent to reduce drilling until oil prices recover. With this in mind, in 2016, we intend to reduce our activity to 2 rigs at the end of February compared to an average of 8.5 rigs in 2015 and 17 rigs in 2014.
Our 2016 capital budget for the Bakken is $425 million, approximately a 70% reduction from 2015. We plan to drill approximately 50 wells and bring approximately 80 new wells online in 2016 compared to 219 new wells online in 2015. Despite this significant reduction in well activity, we forecast Bakken net production to average between 95,000 and 105,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2016 and also in the first quarter of 2016.
Moving to the Utica. In 2015, the joint venture drilled 24 wells and brought 32 new wells on production. In the fourth quarter, net production averaged 30,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day compared to 13,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the year-ago quarter. Net production for the year in the Utica averaged 24,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day compared to 9,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2014. 
In 2015, by applying the same lean manufacturing techniques that we used in the Bakken, we reduced drilling and completion costs by 30%, down to $9.6 million per well from $13.7 million per well in 2014. Despite the high quality of our acreage position and low 5% average royalty, the joint venture intends to lay down the 1 rig we have operating at the end of the first quarter of 2016 given low natural gas and NGL prices and wide basin differentials. 
In 2016, we plan to drill 5 wells and bring 14 new wells online. Production is forecast to average between 20,000 and 25,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2016.
Turning to our offshore operations. In the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, we commenced remediation work at our Tubular Bells Field, in which Hess holds a 57.1% working interest and is operator. This work includes asset jobs at 2 wells and opening a sac subsurface safety valve at another well. The field produced approximately 20,000 net barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2015, and we forecast that the remediation work will allow production to increase to approximately 25,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day over 2016. 
In Norway, at the BP-operated Valhall Field, in which Hess has a 64% interest, production averaged 33,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2015. In response to low prices, the operator plans a very minimal amount of activity in 2016. Full-year net production is expected to average approximately 30,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2016.
At the South Armfield in Denmark, which Hess operates with a 61.5% interest, we expect to complete the current phase of development drilling and release the rig at the end of the first quarter. Net production averaged 13,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2015 and is expected to average approximately 15,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2016. 
In Equatorial Guinea, where we are operator with an 85% interest, we recently completed the acquisition of new 4D seismic. Processing of this seismic is underway, and the early data indicates additional infill production and water injection well opportunities that can be pursued when oil prices recover. Net production averaged 43,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2015. Looking forward, production is expected to decline over 2016, reflecting a continuation of the drilling pause that has been in place since mid-2015. 
At the Malaysia/Thailand Joint Development Area in the Gulf of Thailand, in which Hess has a 50% interest, work continues on the booster compression project which is expected to be completed in the third quarter. Further drilling activity will not be required to meet contracted volumes for the next couple of years as a result of the compression project.  Net production averaged 42,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2015 and is expected to be approximately 35,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2016, reflecting planned downtime associated with the booster compression project and lower PSC entitlements due to lower capital expenditure. 
We continue to progress our North Malay Basin and Stampede developments, which remain on target to come on stream in 2017 and 2018, respectively. At North Malay Basin in the Gulf of Thailand, in which Hess holds a 50% interest and is operator, the first 2 wells of the development drilling campaign have reached total depth and are fully in line with pre-drill expectations. Net production averaged approximately 40 million cubic feet per day through the early production system in 2015 and is expected to stay at this level through 2016. Following completion of the full field development project in 2017, net production is planned to increase to 165 million cubic feet per day. 
At the Stampede development in the Gulf of Mexico, in which Hess holds a 25% working interest and is operator, we successfully completed installation of piles, started setting equipment on the top side and made good progress on the whole in 2015. Looking forward, in 2016, we aim to complete the top side's main deck, begin offshore installation of the whole block and install a subsea system. Development drilling will commence in 2016 and first oil remains targeted for 2018.
Moving to exploration. In the Gulf of Mexico, following the success of the Sicily 1 discovery well, in which Hess holds a 25% interest, the operator Chevron has commenced drilling the Sicily 2 appraisal well to delineate a large 4-way closure in the outward. The operator expects to reach target depth during the second quarter of 2016. 
Also in the Gulf of Mexico, we are participating in a ConocoPhillips-operated prospect called Melmar in which Hess has a 35% interest. The lower price environment has enabled access to high-quality, longer-term offshore prospects at attractive entry costs. Melmar is a good example of this and fits well with our strategy. It is one of the last large Paleogene 4-way prospects in the prolific trend. Drilling operations began in December, and the operator expects to reach total depth in the second quarter 2016. 
In Guyana, where the Liza 1 well encountered [ph] 295 feet of high-quality oilbearing reservoir, the operator, Exxon Exploration and Production Guyana Limited, is planning to evaluate the Liza discovery and test the further potential of the Stabroek Block, in which Hess has a 30% interest. The next well, Liza 2, is planned to spud later in the first quarter.
In closing, despite the challenging price environment, 2015 was a year of excellent execution and delivery across our business, which is a tribute to the outstanding people of Hess. Our strategy is to continue protecting our balance sheet while maintaining our core capabilities and growth options. I will now turn the call over to John Reilly.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. In my remarks today, I will compare results from the fourth quarter of 2015 to the third quarter of 2015. Our adjusted net loss, which excludes items affecting comparability of earnings between periods, was $396 million in the fourth quart
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. In my remarks today, I will compare results from the fourth quarter of 2015 to the third quarter of 2015. 
Our adjusted net loss, which excludes items affecting comparability of earnings between periods, was $396 million in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to $291 million in the third quarter of 2015. On a GAAP basis, the Corporation incurred a net loss of $1,821,000,000 in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared with a net loss of $279 million in the previous quarter. 
The fourth quarter results contained noncash charges of $1,359,000,000 resulting from the low commodity price environment, including the writeoff of our E&P segment goodwill of $1,098,000,000. The nontaxable goodwill charge was allocated in our financial results to U.S. and international operations. 
In addition, fourth quarter exploration expenses include $178 million after tax for the write off of previously capitalized gas wells in Ghana, 3 previously capitalized wells in Australia that are not included in the most recent development concept and the impairment of certain leasehold costs in the Gulf of Mexico. In the United States, we also recognized an impairment charge of $83 million after tax associated with our legacy conventional North Dakota assets. 
In connection with the sale of Hovensa's assets and completion of its bankruptcy, Hess agreed to assume obligations under the Hovensa pension plan and relinquish our rights to receive any proceeds from financing provided to Hovensa during bankruptcy in exchange for the release of all claims from the Virgin Islands government that were asserted against us. Our fourth quarter results include charges of $41 million after tax for the cost of the pension obligations amounts funded in the quarter and legal fees.
Turning to E&P. On an adjusted basis, E&P incurred losses of $328 million in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to a loss of $221 million in the third quarter of 2015. The changes in the after-tax components of adjusted results for E&P between the fourth quarter of 2015 and the third quarter of 2015 were as follows: Lower sales volumes reduced results by $46 million, lower realized selling prices reduced results by $33 million, higher exploration expenses reduced results by $21 million. All other items net to a reduction results in $7 million for an overall reduction in fourth quarter adjusted results of $107 million. In the fourth quarter, our E&P operations were underlifted compared with production by approximately 1 million barrels, which did not have a material impact on fourth-quarter results. 
The E&P effective income tax rate, excluding items affecting comparability, was a benefit of 38% for the fourth quarter of 2015 compared with a benefit of 47% in the third quarter. On an adjusted basis, the fourth quarter effective tax rate reflects the fact that goodwill impairment charge did not have an associated tax benefit.
Turning to Midstream. Fourth-quarter net income of $11 million was down versus third quarter net income of $16 million, primarily due to lower volume throughput at the Tioga Gas Plant as a result of unplanned downtime and increased crude export via pipeline in response to market differentials. Bakken Midstream EBITDA, excluding the noncontrolling interest, amounted to $67 million in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to $79 million in the previous quarter.
Turning to Corporate. After-tax Corporate and interest expenses, excluding items affecting comparability, were $79 million in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to $86 million in the third quarter of 2015.
Turning to cash flow. Net cash provided by operating activities in the fourth quarter, including an increase of $401 million from changes in working capital, was $623 million. Additions to property, plant and equipment were $935 million. Net borrowings were $93 million. Common stock dividends paid were $72 million. Other net amounted to a use of cash of $6 million, resulting in a net decrease in cash and cash equivalents in the fourth quarter of $297 million. 
Excluding amounts held in our Bakken midstream joint venture, we had approximately $2.7 billion of cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2015, compared to $3 billion at September 30, 2015. Total debt, excluding Bakken Midstream, was $5.9 billion at December 31, 2015, and our debt to capitalization ratio was 24.4%. In addition, we have a committed $4 billion revolving credit facility that is undrawn.
Turning to 2016 guidance. We project cash cost for E&P operations to be in the range of $15 to $16 per barrel of oil equivalent in the first quarter of 2016 and $14.50 to $15.50 per barrel for the full-year 2016, down from 2015 cash cost of $15.69 per barrel. The first quarter cash costs include well work over cost at the Tubular Bells Field. 
DD&A per barrel of oil equivalent for the first quarter of 2016 is forecast to be $29 to $30 per barrel and $28.50 to $29.50 per barrel for the full year of 2016, up from 2015  DD&A of $28.14 per barrel. This results in projected total E&P unit operating cost of $44 to $46 per barrel in the first quarter of 2016 and $43 to $45 per barrel for the full year of 2016 compared with 2015 E&P unit operating cost of $43.83 per barrel. 
The Bakken midstream tariff expense is expected to be $3.55 to $3.65 per barrel of oil equivalent for the first quarter of 2016 and $3.55 to $3.95 per barrel of oil equivalent for the full year of 2016, up from 2015 midstream tariffs of $3.28 per barrel. 
Exploration expenses, excluding dry hole costs and items affecting comparability, are expected to be in the range of $65 million to $75 million in the first quarter of 2016 and $260 million to $280 million for the full year 2016, down from $338 million in 2015. 
The E&P effective tax rate, excluding Libya, is expected to be a deferred tax benefit in the range of 41% to 45% for the first quarter and full year of 2016 versus a benefit of 45% in 2015.
Turning to Midstream. In 2016, we anticipate net income attributable to Hess from the Bakken Midstream segment, which reflects our 50% ownership, to be in the range of $10 million to $15 million in the first quarter and in the range of $40 million to $50 million for the full year.
Turning to Corporate and interest. In 2016, we estimate Corporate expenses net of taxes to be in the range of $25 million to $35 million in the first quarter and in the range of $110 million to $120 million for the full year. We estimate interest expense to be in the range of $50 million to $55 million in the first quarter of 2016 and in the range of $205 million to $215 million for the full-year 2016. 
This concludes my remarks. We will be happy to answer any questions. I will now turn the call over to the operator.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, I've got a couple if I may. First question is to John Reilly. John, the cash flow number you gave was net of working capital. But can you, ex the working capital, again cash flow looked a bit light. Can you walk us through what's going on
componenttext: First question, I've got a couple if I may. First question is to John Reilly. John, the cash flow number you gave was net of working capital. But can you, ex the working capital, again cash flow looked a bit light. Can you walk us through what's going on with particularly deferred tax and any other unusual items that explain that number? And I've got a couple of exploration follow-ups, please.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So in the fourth quarter, we did have some special charges in the fourth quarter and some of them do have a cash flow impact. So they are impacting what a normal run rate would be in the fourth quarter. So the first part of that in the E&P charges a
componenttext: Sure. So in the fourth quarter, we did have some special charges in the fourth quarter and some of them do have a cash flow impact. So they are impacting what a normal run rate would be in the fourth quarter. So the first part of that in the E&P charges are first surplus materials and supplies just due to reduced drilling plans. So that was approximately $25 million in the quarter that was reducing cash flow that 2 21. And then also we had lower cost of market in the fourth quarter of approximately $40 million. So those 2 right there from a special charges aspect gets you about $65 million kind of a nonrecurring impact in the quarter. And then there's a couple of other things. One, from the specials outside of the E&P is Hovensa. So part of the charge relates to the relinquishments of proceeds that we provided during bankruptcy, plus we had legal fees in there. So that was approximately $20 million in the quarter, again reducing cash flow from operations. And then on an operating standpoint, you probably saw you noticed our exploration costs were up in the quarter. Just from a run rate standpoint, it was in line with our full-year guidance. But in the fourth quarter, we had higher seismic, approximately $20 million to $25 million in the quarter. So again from a recurring type standpoint, it's just impacting that lower cash flow in the fourth quarter. And then the last thing you heard I did mention there was 1 million-barrel underlift. So even though that had from a results standpoint not much of an impact, it does have a cash flow impact in the quarter. And so you're ranging that $10 million to $15 million for that underlift. So all told, it's about $125 million when you add those numbers kind of reducing the cash flow from operations in the quarter.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes a ton of sense, makes and reconciles the number. My follow-up to the extent you can answer on to 2 nonoperated exploration wells. I mean, clearly, exploration is getting no market right now. But this looks like, to John's comments, look like th
componenttext: That makes a ton of sense, makes and reconciles the number. My follow-up to the extent you can answer on to 2 nonoperated exploration wells. I mean, clearly, exploration is getting no market right now. But this looks like, to John's comments, look like they could be pretty material. So Greg, on first of all, on Melmar, can you walk us through the genesis of how you got in this market spending additional capital on exploration might seems surprising to some. So what's the Genesis of your entry there on -- to the extent you can talk about the prospect. My understanding is this is a $2 billion to $4 billion oil in place target. I mean, are those numbers right? And how would you risk it? I've got a follow-up on Liza, please.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on Melmar let me just open, Doug, of course, we are in a long term business and we need to both think about today and tomorrow. So and one of the things we're seeing is this low price environment has created a lot of opportunities to access very high q
componenttext: So on Melmar let me just open, Doug, of course, we are in a long term business and we need to both think about today and tomorrow. So and one of the things we're seeing is this low price environment has created a lot of opportunities to access very high quality longer-term growth options at very competitive entry costs. So Melmar is a great example of that. Melmar, if you look at it, it's a very large four-way on the proven prolific trend. So we farmed in to a 35% working interest position on all 8 blocks covered by the structure. I think importantly, it's one of the last undrilled large Paleogene 4 ways in the trend and therefore has a very high chance of geologic success. The second thing about it, it's got a water depth of about 5,200 feet. Now that's compared to 7,900 feet at Great White. And so what that means is it has higher projected reservoir pressures compared to Great White. The development cost could be significantly lower given the shallower depth. And importantly, the property that porosity and permeability and deliverability are also going to be likely be the best in the trend. So when you look at the prospect, it was one of these really quality prospects that you get in at very low entry cost. So that's why we did it.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My final one, if I may, is also an exploration, Greg, again I realized Exxon is operator, so the constraints surround you. But you did put $70 million in your budget for predevelopment. I'm just wondering what that means? And again, you had real qua
componenttext: Okay. My final one, if I may, is also an exploration, Greg, again I realized Exxon is operator, so the constraints surround you. But you did put $70 million in your budget for predevelopment. I'm just wondering what that means? And again, you had real quality with Melmar. We're hearing that the rock quality in Liza could be kind off the chart. So if you can give some color there and maybe some ideas on what production system might look like, acknowledging that it's only one well and perhaps we're getting a little bit any color you can provide would be helpful.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first of all, the rock property is fantastic, very good porosity, very good permeability for deepwater at this depth. It is truly almost an outlier in that respect. Regarding the Early Production System, we have money in our budget to begin looking at
componenttext: So first of all, the rock property is fantastic, very good porosity, very good permeability for deepwater at this depth. It is truly almost an outlier in that respect. Regarding the Early Production System, we have money in our budget to begin looking at the development options. Obviously, the development options will be dependent upon what you figure out in the appraisal program. So other than that, we can't really be specific because it depends on what we find in the appraisal program. So -- but very good, very exciting Guyana province here.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just the market obviously with the low strip prices is very focused on outspend. Obviously, you're spending 820 on the 2 developments and when they come on stream you will get the cash flow from that, that's pretty obvious. But in terms of the next wave o
componenttext: Just the market obviously with the low strip prices is very focused on outspend. Obviously, you're spending 820 on the 2 developments and when they come on stream you will get the cash flow from that, that's pretty obvious. But in terms of the next wave of spending around Guyana or the Lower Tertiary, I'm just trying to get a sense of are there any sort of lease terms which might force you into spending money even if the oil price stays low? I'm trying to get a sense of a way of asking 2017 exploration spend and development spend and maybe a trajectory into 2018.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ed. The way we look at it and obviously as Greg said the Guyana is an exciting opportunity for us. And you kind of laid it out. With North Malay Basin coming on stream in 2017 turning into a cash generator and Stampede following in 2018, we don't re
componenttext: Sure, Ed. The way we look at it and obviously as Greg said the Guyana is an exciting opportunity for us. And you kind of laid it out. With North Malay Basin coming on stream in 2017 turning into a cash generator and Stampede following in 2018, we don't really see any significant development spend coming our way from Guyana in 2017 and 2018. We see further exploration spending coming in. So the bigger development spend will be coming in fitting nicely into our portfolio as North Malay Basin and Stampede come. So I can't really give you any specific guidance, but that's how we think about the spending going over the next couple of years.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the Bakken. Obviously, with 2 rigs, it feels like you're going to be drawing down some undeveloped drilled but uncompleted inventory. Maybe just an update as you roll if you roll the 2 program out into 2017, what the impact would be
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the Bakken. Obviously, with 2 rigs, it feels like you're going to be drawing down some undeveloped drilled but uncompleted inventory. Maybe just an update as you roll if you roll the 2 program out into 2017, what the impact would be on Bakken production.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, with the 2 rig program, we feel pretty confident that we can hold production in that range of 95,000 to 105,000 a day through 2016. If you think about how that trajectory is going to unfold though throughout '16, it's going to start the year at the hi
componenttext: Ed, with the 2 rig program, we feel pretty confident that we can hold production in that range of 95,000 to 105,000 a day through 2016. If you think about how that trajectory is going to unfold though throughout '16, it's going to start the year at the high-end of the range and it's going to end the year at the lower end of the range. So if you fast-forward to 2017 and said I held 2 rigs through 2017, obviously, you would see some decline year-on-year. You can't hold it flat for more than a year with 2 rigs.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Cheng of Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Cheng of Barclays.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious, I mean just 3 months ago when you were talking about the guidance of the budget, a 4 rig program for Bakken, we're talking about 95 to 105 and now with 2 rigs. Over the last 3 months, what may have changed that to make you increase the confi
componenttext: Just curious, I mean just 3 months ago when you were talking about the guidance of the budget, a 4 rig program for Bakken, we're talking about 95 to 105 and now with 2 rigs. Over the last 3 months, what may have changed that to make you increase the confidence that only 2 rigs and you actually also dropped the number of well going to be onstream next year from 100 to 80, but you keep the guidance to be you said it just that 3 months ago the guidance you actually feel like you could be able to reach the high end and now that smaller in the middle or in the low end? Just trying to understand.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Really, there's 4 factors. So first of all, the 2 rig program is really focused in the core of the core, with the higher EURs and IP rates. I think the second factor is we've increased the stage count from 35 being our standard design to 50
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. Really, there's 4 factors. So first of all, the 2 rig program is really focused in the core of the core, with the higher EURs and IP rates. I think the second factor is we've increased the stage count from 35 being our standard design to 50 stage frac is our standard. And if you look at the impact of the 50 stage design, we are seeing about a 20% increase in IP 30, 60 and 90. So obviously, that's going to carry through. I think the third thing is, we're going to have increased gas and NGL capture in the plant as the Hawkeye South of the river system comes on in the third quarter of the year. And then the last is just increased drilling efficiencies. So further reductions in spud days. So it's really all 4 of those factors add up to you can still hold the range even with the to rig program.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Greg, look like the $600 million cut from the previous guidance, $300 million appears to be from the major projects because I thought the previously you're talking about $1.5 billion in the major project and now it's about $1.2 billion, including the
componenttext: And Greg, look like the $600 million cut from the previous guidance, $300 million appears to be from the major projects because I thought the previously you're talking about $1.5 billion in the major project and now it's about $1.2 billion, including the exploration or appraisal during in Guyana in Northern. Where's that $300 million has been reduced from?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, I can answer this I guess maybe just a little bit more broadly. But of that $600 million, about half of it is due to cost savings. So we are seeing further cost savings from the numbers that we had provided in October. So we are getting about $300 m
componenttext: Paul, I can answer this I guess maybe just a little bit more broadly. But of that $600 million, about half of it is due to cost savings. So we are seeing further cost savings from the numbers that we had provided in October. So we are getting about $300 million there across. And some of it is in the development projects, some of it is in our existing assets. And then the other half like reducing to the 2 rigs in the Bakken is due to the deferral of activity.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. And then, John, since you're here, Algeria, the asset sales, have you already closed before the end of the year? In other words, is the money already in your balance sheet? Or that we should expect that in the first quarter? And in that case, how m
componenttext: I see. And then, John, since you're here, Algeria, the asset sales, have you already closed before the end of the year? In other words, is the money already in your balance sheet? Or that we should expect that in the first quarter? And in that case, how much is that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: So the actual transaction did close right before year end. However, we have not received the cash yet. That will be coming in the first quarter. The contract though is confidential. I can't give you the number on that. But it is not a significant amount.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: So when you say not significant, does that mean less than 100?

componenttext: You can estimate that, Paul, yes.

componenttext: Okay. That's fine. And I just want to clarify, I have to apologize when you speak I didn't jot it down correctly maybe. You're saying that the cash at the end of the year excluding the Bakken John mentioned is $2.3 billion [indiscernible]

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from of CLSA.
componenttext: And our next question comes from of CLSA.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, if I may, on the cost structure. Historically, when looking at the Bakken, Greg, I think you mentioned OpEx per barrel split of 40% variable, 60% fixed. With a variable cost should be a benefit from lower energy component. But there
componenttext: A couple of questions, if I may, on the cost structure. Historically, when looking at the Bakken, Greg, I think you mentioned OpEx per barrel split of 40% variable, 60% fixed. With a variable cost should be a benefit from lower energy component. But there could be several moving parts in the fixed component particularly as it relates to lower field personnel cost. Can you update us on that? So that's number one. Number two, DD&A per barrel, that number should also trend lower over the medium term. Can you discuss sort of the potential trajectory? And then third, the cost structure, Stampede, first oil expected in 2018? I know the rigs have been contracted. What percent of the project cost is yet to be committed?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll try to answer all 3 of you. So the first one, you're focusing on the Bakken, but this does apply across the portfolio that we do have high -- I mean, there's a good amount of the costs that are fixed. And so obviously, we are trying to attack t
componenttext: Okay, I'll try to answer all 3 of you. So the first one, you're focusing on the Bakken, but this does apply across the portfolio that we do have high -- I mean, there's a good amount of the costs that are fixed. And so obviously, we are trying to attack the fixed cost in this low-price environment as well as the variable cost and making sure we get all the variable cost out as we reduce activity. So we have been seeing from let's just pick the Bakken on our cash cost per barrel, we've been seeing significant reductions like if you go back from the first quarter of 2014 or through the fourth quarter 2015, we've been seeing significant cost reductions on our cash cost per barrel. And you probably heard when I gave the 2016 guidance, we are giving guidance that our cash costs per barrel are going down in 2016, and that's with a reduction from 368,000 barrels a day pro forma production down to a 3 30 to 3 50. So we are trying to stay up with especially in this low oil price environment reducing fixed costs and variable cost. And so we are attacking both of them. As far as DD&A from our trajectory standpoint, you heard from our guidance actually our DD&A was going up in 2016, and that it's directly related to the reserves. So you heard the reserves are going down from the price revisions. So with those lower reserve amounts that's going to increase our DD&A as prices recover within those reserves come right back on the book. And so in a normal environment, what would be happening say in the Bakken is that as we continue to add reserves for our performance and additional drilling and know that we've got all the infrastructure spend kind of behind us, our DD& a would be going down over time. As far as Stampede, I'm going to hand it back to Greg for that.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So thanks for that. Stampede, if you look at most of the costs have already been committed, but we have taken advantage of the lower price and service environment and actually got some savings from Stampede. As we put in our capital press release yes
componenttext: Yes. So thanks for that. Stampede, if you look at most of the costs have already been committed, but we have taken advantage of the lower price and service environment and actually got some savings from Stampede. As we put in our capital press release yesterday, we'll spend about $325 million in 2016 in Stampede.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And just a follow-up on Guyana. Could you talk about well costs? I know Liza was probably less than $80 million, I think you mentioned. And could you remind us of the environment, what are that, et cetera? If you could.
componenttext: That's very helpful. And just a follow-up on Guyana. Could you talk about well costs? I know Liza was probably less than $80 million, I think you mentioned. And could you remind us of the environment, what are that, et cetera? If you could.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're right. Liza was less than $80 million net to us. Regarding future well cost, you're going to have to refer to the operator. What I will say is obviously the appraisal wells will be higher cost because we are doing lots of testing and pouring and th
componenttext: You're right. Liza was less than $80 million net to us. Regarding future well cost, you're going to have to refer to the operator. What I will say is obviously the appraisal wells will be higher cost because we are doing lots of testing and pouring and the normal things that you would do in the appraisal part of the program.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from David Heikkinen of Heikkinen Energy Advisors.
componenttext: And our next question comes from David Heikkinen of Heikkinen Energy Advisors.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Have one high-level question and one kind of lower level. What do you expect your year-end 2016 cash to be?
componenttext: Have one high-level question and one kind of lower level. What do you expect your year-end 2016 cash to be?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, that's -- let me go through. I'll tell you how I think you should be looking at 2016. So we finished the year, as you know, with $2.7 billion of cash. And obviously, we're going to have cash flow from operations in 2016. So as we just released yest
componenttext: David, that's -- let me go through. I'll tell you how I think you should be looking at 2016. So we finished the year, as you know, with $2.7 billion of cash. And obviously, we're going to have cash flow from operations in 2016. So as we just released yesterday, you saw our capital spend program is estimated to be $2.4 billion in 2016. In that $2.4 billion is approximately $200 million of exploration cash spend like seismic and G&A that's part of cash flow. So we have to fund capital expenditures of $2.2 billion. And we have our dividend of approximately $285 million. Let me just round that to 300. So our capital and our dividend is going to be $2.5 billion in 2016. We have a cash balance at the end of '15 of $2.7 billion. So effectively, we can fund our capital program and our dividend out of our cash balance and still have $200 million left over at the end of 2016. And obviously, we'd still have a revolver undrawn. So then with that $200 million left in the cash account, David, I am going to give you some work to do here because now you have to estimate what the cash flow from operations are going to be in 2016, and that depends on your commodity price assumption. So we have given you the production guidance, the cash cost guidance and whatever cash flow from operations that you then come to, you can add to that $200 million, and that's where we'll sit. So we're in a good liquidity position coming into this year, and I think that's how you have to look at 2016.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You didn't want to fill in the blank that I was looking for, that's fair enough. On the other side, Greg, the new stage count is pretty impressive. And then you're coring up. So just trying to get an idea of 2016 Bakken development, give an idea of what 3
componenttext: You didn't want to fill in the blank that I was looking for, that's fair enough. On the other side, Greg, the new stage count is pretty impressive. And then you're coring up. So just trying to get an idea of 2016 Bakken development, give an idea of what 30, 60 and 90 day rates would be? Just round numbers would be helpful on the [indiscernible]

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we have given guidance before and we'll be at the upper end of that range, obviously, because we are in the core of the core of the Bakken. So our previous guidance will be in the high end of the range.
componenttext: I think we have given guidance before and we'll be at the upper end of that range, obviously, because we are in the core of the core of the Bakken. So our previous guidance will be in the high end of the range.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seems like you're double dipping with the new wells and core of the core that would have even above that range, potentially.
componenttext: Seems like you're double dipping with the new wells and core of the core that would have even above that range, potentially.

componenttext: It will be once we have the 50 stage frac. So we need to update our guidance once we get [indiscernible]

componenttext: We'll roll that Q2 [ph]. And then just net-net of everything, what's your Bakken net back expected to be in the first quarter?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We never really try to forecast because it's so difficult quarter-to-quarter. So in the fourth quarter, we were at Bakken was getting between $6 and $7 under TI. And again, the economics are right now favoring more to pipe than rail.
componenttext: We never really try to forecast because it's so difficult quarter-to-quarter. So in the fourth quarter, we were at Bakken was getting between $6 and $7 under TI. And again, the economics are right now favoring more to pipe than rail.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: About 75% of our volume now is on pipe. And the clear book differential that goes into that $6 number that John was just talking is a discount to WTI is maybe $2.50 off refineries during turnaround, that number was about 1 50 before. So there's about a $1
componenttext: About 75% of our volume now is on pipe. And the clear book differential that goes into that $6 number that John was just talking is a discount to WTI is maybe $2.50 off refineries during turnaround, that number was about 1 50 before. So there's about a $1 weakness now. But as refineries come back on, we expect that to recover.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Guy Baber of Simmons and Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Guy Baber of Simmons and Company.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You all have consistently mentioned that preserving your operating capability is a key objective for the company, and that's the strategic question for me, particularly in the Bakken. But can you talk about striking that balance between cutting CapEx and
componenttext: You all have consistently mentioned that preserving your operating capability is a key objective for the company, and that's the strategic question for me, particularly in the Bakken. But can you talk about striking that balance between cutting CapEx and rigs to protect the balance sheet versus preserving your capabilities so that you can respond in a timely manner when you get the appropriate oil price signal? Is that a concern for you guys with 2 rigs running? And is it a concern for you all for the industry at large in the Bakken from what you can see?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for that question. It is striking the balance, and I think with our budgets and operating 2 rigs in the Bakken, we think we've achieved the right balance. So we're doing creative things with doubling of people and moving them over to special assign
componenttext: Thanks for that question. It is striking the balance, and I think with our budgets and operating 2 rigs in the Bakken, we think we've achieved the right balance. So we're doing creative things with doubling of people and moving them over to special assignments and all that, making sure that they're ready for the inevitable ramp-up that will come in the Bakken.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up is on the committed CapEx going for thinking through '17 and '18, we know that major product spending long lead time obligations of falling off over the next few years. But can you give us any specific indications as to how muc
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up is on the committed CapEx going for thinking through '17 and '18, we know that major product spending long lead time obligations of falling off over the next few years. But can you give us any specific indications as to how much declines in 2017 is the majority of the North Malay Basin CapEx in '16? You're not going to have that spending commitment in '17 or is that more of an '18 event? Just trying to get a better sense there, I think it would help us better appreciate and understand the evolution of the free cash flow profile enough flat oil price environment, which is an important consideration.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So from a commitment standpoint, what we'd be looking at over the next couple of years is to complete North Malay Basin, complete Stampede and, obviously, continue the exploration that we have going on, in particular in Guyana. So in 2017, North Mal
componenttext: Sure. So from a commitment standpoint, what we'd be looking at over the next couple of years is to complete North Malay Basin, complete Stampede and, obviously, continue the exploration that we have going on, in particular in Guyana. So in 2017, North Malay Basin will be coming online. So we have $375 million in the budget this year that is essentially reducing our free cash flow by that $375 million. Now we don't have exactly what the budget will be for North Malay Basin next year as far as pure capital, but it will be considerably lower than the $375 million. But again, no matter what that number is, it will be generating free cash flow. So as you look to 2017, we will get an improvement of free cash flow just related to North Malay Basin of $375 million. And then again, you follow on that with Stampede, so you have $325 million this year not generating free cash flow. Again, we don't have the budget set for '17. I don't expect it to be that different in '17 as you move forward with Stampede. And so it won't be until '18 that you'll turn around that $325 million of free cash flow.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Evan Calio of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Evan Calio of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sort of a follow-up to prior cash question. What do you guys consider the minimum operating cash limits on the balance sheet? And I realize on most of the math that you supplied before in the call, you currently support the dividend given your balance she
componenttext: Sort of a follow-up to prior cash question. What do you guys consider the minimum operating cash limits on the balance sheet? And I realize on most of the math that you supplied before in the call, you currently support the dividend given your balance sheet strength. How do you consider the dividend strategy in the context of constrained cash flow environment and the amount of the breadth of longer-term investment opportunities that you have as you navigate towards [ph] '16?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Evan. Again, as we go through that, we are just in a good position relative to our competition with this $2.7 billion of cash. We don't need any cash flow from operations to fund our capital program as I mentioned of 2.2  plus the dividend and if I
componenttext: Sure, Evan. Again, as we go through that, we are just in a good position relative to our competition with this $2.7 billion of cash. We don't need any cash flow from operations to fund our capital program as I mentioned of 2.2  plus the dividend and if I round to $300 million. So we can fund that completely out of our cash account and have $200 million left over in there. And there will be, if you want to sit at a minimum level, you're somewhere around that say the $200 million that you want to at least keep in our system between the U.S. and internationally. But again, we don't even need any cash flow from operations just to repeat that to fund that capital or dividend. So anything I get as you'd estimate for cash flow from operations we just get added do that cash balance, we won't be near this any minimum level as it relates to cash.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. A couple of smaller follow-up items. Can you give a cost or EUR uplift from the 50 stage Bakken completions versus the 35 stage design?
componenttext: That makes sense. A couple of smaller follow-up items. Can you give a cost or EUR uplift from the 50 stage Bakken completions versus the 35 stage design?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you look at 2015, particularly at the back half of the year when we had a lot of 50 stagers coming online, we were at the top end of our guidance range. So the 5 50 the [ph] 6 50, we were at the very top end of that. We averaged 6 50 for the wh
componenttext: Yes. So if you look at 2015, particularly at the back half of the year when we had a lot of 50 stagers coming online, we were at the top end of our guidance range. So the 5 50 the [ph] 6 50, we were at the very top end of that. We averaged 6 50 for the whole year in 2015. And as we drill in the core of the core next year and do the 50 stage fracs, we expected to be in the high 600 to the mid-700 range. So you're seeing that uplift. Also on the IP rates, you could see a similar sort of effect. I mean, the range we've given on IP rates is 800 to 950. And obviously, with the 50 stage fracs on the IP rates, you're going to be up there. One other point I want to make about the well cost in the Bakken, the well cost for the fourth quarter averaged $5.1 million per well, which is about a 28% reduction from the year ago and a 4% reduction from Q3. Again, that lean manufacturing machine just continuing to work. We said that we expect cost next year to be broadly flat at that $5 million to $5.1 million per well level. But of course, that math, the significant amount of ongoing improvement because embedded in that number of the 5 1 is a 40% increase in stage on. So we expect to fully offset that increase in cost due to the higher stage count with continued lean manufacturing gains. So again, a 20% uplift in production for basically the same cost is what you have this year. So obviously, that's going to be good for returns.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I guess a similar spud the spot, is it that 18 day or what that number is we should assume?
componenttext: And then I guess a similar spud the spot, is it that 18 day or what that number is we should assume?

componenttext: Yes. It will improve again next year. I mean, this year, we averaged about 22 wells per rig during the year. That's going to increase to say 24 or so next year.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Great. And lastly for me, small one, if you can share what you booked on North Malay expansion in 2016? Just want to know how much of the project value is potentially reflected in your reserve numbers?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that was not -- there's no addition to our reserves in 2015 for the North Malay Basin expansion.
componenttext: No, that was not -- there's no addition to our reserves in 2015 for the North Malay Basin expansion.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a number of what that -- what's in there? What you booked or what you have as spuds there?
componenttext: Can you give us a number of what that -- what's in there? What you booked or what you have as spuds there?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So what we have for North Malay Basin, and this is kind if you get into this unique reserve accounting rules, because we don't -- during 2015, we did not have a significant amount of wells in the ground that we could book proved reserves on. And as
componenttext: Okay. So what we have for North Malay Basin, and this is kind if you get into this unique reserve accounting rules, because we don't -- during 2015, we did not have a significant amount of wells in the ground that we could book proved reserves on. And as Greg mentioned, we started the drilling program more now kicking it off in '16 to drill of the reservoirs, we didn't have that significant of reserves initially. And then when you run it through the reserve accounting requirements, because those proved reserves are low compared to the gas sale contract, we can't book the reserves here in 2015. So what will happen is Greg's team just drills out in 2016 we'll actually begin booking the reserves at North Malay Basin.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Bryan Singer of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Bryan Singer of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to follow up on some of the Guyana questions. You mentioned that the early production system depends on the appraisal program. Can you talk more specifically about what you expect to learn with the Liza number 2 and then the same kind of question f
componenttext: Wanted to follow up on some of the Guyana questions. You mentioned that the early production system depends on the appraisal program. Can you talk more specifically about what you expect to learn with the Liza number 2 and then the same kind of question for how the next 3 wells that you're drilling and planning this year differ and what the learnings could be from those wells as well.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's talk about Liza appraisal first, I mean we want to get a dynamic test. That will tell us about potential compartmentalization in Liza. We also want to find where the contact is. So that will be the primary 2 objectives of the appraisal wells in Liza
componenttext: Let's talk about Liza appraisal first, I mean we want to get a dynamic test. That will tell us about potential compartmentalization in Liza. We also want to find where the contact is. So that will be the primary 2 objectives of the appraisal wells in Liza. The exploration wells are basically the objective there is to figure out what we're seeing on seismic, is that replicable in other areas of the block because we have a lot of look-a-likes on seismic. So we want to get a well or 2, a couple of those other things and see what running room we have on the block. We think there's a lot but obviously you'll need some more wells to figure that out.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then my follow-up is with regards to M&A. You mentioned really going back a year valuations never really looked attractive from a consolidation perspective. And I wondered, a, if you can kind of comment on how it looks now? And then, b, recogni
componenttext: Great. And then my follow-up is with regards to M&A. You mentioned really going back a year valuations never really looked attractive from a consolidation perspective. And I wondered, a, if you can kind of comment on how it looks now? And then, b, recognizing that preserving balance sheet is one of your key objectives, is the opportunities that you now see at Guyana especially so meaningful that it reduces your interest level and even considering feel consolidation?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look. Fair question on M&A. We always look at the outside to see if there are opportunities that will make our portfolio stronger, improve our economic opportunities for investment and also not sacrifice our balance sheet strength. And while values have c
componenttext: Look. Fair question on M&A. We always look at the outside to see if there are opportunities that will make our portfolio stronger, improve our economic opportunities for investment and also not sacrifice our balance sheet strength. And while values have come down, just to reiterate, while our priority is, first and foremost, the strength of our balance sheet and obviously the company's really well positioned with our $2.7 billion of cash at the end of the year, one of the strongest balance sheets and liquidity positions among our peers, we further strengthened that balance sheet by the further reduction in our spending for 2016 to the $2.4 billion number we're talking about, it's about value, not volume, so the whole focus is the balance sheet. And yet at the same time, it's a very important that the company, we are in a long-term business, everybody's thinking short-term, that we invest for future growth on a disciplined and focused basis and we feel we are extremely well-positioned with the growth options that we have both in North Malay Basin and Stampede, but also obviously Guyana, that the company is going to benefit quite a bit and our shareholders as well as oil prices recover ultimately with these growth options that we've already assembled. So we feel pretty good about what we've already captured, and therefore, M&A is very low on the priority list.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Roger Read of Wells Fargo.

Do you continue to do testing in this environment or with the 2-well program strictly we should think about it as development and maybe putting further efficiencies on a hold for now? Or is it a drive for further efficiencies?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think part of lean manufacturing is every day you look for the next improvement. So in terms of piloting, though, I think we've done the infills, 9/8 been very successful, 50 stage fracs, been very successful. So those now will become our standard desig
componenttext: I think part of lean manufacturing is every day you look for the next improvement. So in terms of piloting, though, I think we've done the infills, 9/8 been very successful, 50 stage fracs, been very successful. So those now will become our standard design obviously in the core of the core. But every day we're looking for the next improvement, right. So that drive will continue to, that will go on and we are constantly trying to improve everything across our business there and that's all part of the lean manufacturing philosophy.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as you think about and you'd mentioned earlier in the beginning of the call, opportunities in the deepwater, you've been able to get in. Others are struggling on the cash flow side. As you look at some of those partners and you think about
componenttext: Okay. And then as you think about and you'd mentioned earlier in the beginning of the call, opportunities in the deepwater, you've been able to get in. Others are struggling on the cash flow side. As you look at some of those partners and you think about taking these projects for either an appraisal well or ultimately full development if it works out that way, what's sort of, I guess, robots may run into or partners simply don't want to fund those next steps? And how do we -- it's been a long time since we've had a downturn like this. How should we think about the workout of that process over time?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, if you think about what we're in currently, so Sicily, clearly, Chevron wants to move forward or aligned with that in the appraisal ConocoPhillips, obviously, moved forward with Melmar. Guyana moving forward with Exxon Mobil. Nova Scotia,
componenttext: Well, certainly, if you think about what we're in currently, so Sicily, clearly, Chevron wants to move forward or aligned with that in the appraisal ConocoPhillips, obviously, moved forward with Melmar. Guyana moving forward with Exxon Mobil. Nova Scotia, BP, moving forward. So we don't really see any risk of people not wanting to move forward. Regarding your question and the opportunities, there is a lot of opportunity out there, very good prospects, very low entry cost, but we're going to be extremely disciplined. And it's going to have to be really good in order for us to even consider adding it to the mix. And Melmar was one example of something that was very good and we made the decision to get in. But we're going to be extremely disciplined and very selective on how we do that.

componenttext: The first question I wanted to ask was did I understand correctly that the reduced spending in North Malay and Stampede was largely on cost saving? And if so, can you indicate where what sort of savings we are talking about? And also was I correct that the timelines the first oil are intact?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the timelines, the first oil are into. When I was talking about cost savings, it was across the portfolio. We had a mix of that $600 million, where kind of half of it was cost savings and half of it was deferment of activity. So there is a
componenttext: I'll start with the timelines, the first oil are into. When I was talking about cost savings, it was across the portfolio. We had a mix of that $600 million, where kind of half of it was cost savings and half of it was deferment of activity. So there is a mix on North Malay Basin and Stampede. It's not like that was all cost savings.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then thinking about staying on the theme of cost savings in the offshore. I was just wondering, can you comment broadly about your current view of industry efforts to reduce offshore development costs? And specifically, I'm thinking back when yo
componenttext: Okay. And then thinking about staying on the theme of cost savings in the offshore. I was just wondering, can you comment broadly about your current view of industry efforts to reduce offshore development costs? And specifically, I'm thinking back when you said that Guyana looked great at $80 a barrel but not as much of lower oil prices. Other than waiting for a higher future oil price, do you see developments unfolding that can make a play like Guyana better able to attract capital and a better but still moderate oil price environment?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. I mean if you look at cost reductions, if you look at the onshore, I would say the progression of cost reductions in the onshore has been much more rapid than the offshore for very practical reasons, the offshore fleet, there's still a lo
componenttext: Yes, I think so. I mean if you look at cost reductions, if you look at the onshore, I would say the progression of cost reductions in the onshore has been much more rapid than the offshore for very practical reasons, the offshore fleet, there's still a lot of rigs on contract at relatively high prices. The yards are full, still full as you kind of look around the globe. So we see that really opening up as rigs come off contract in the offshore, as yards become not at capacity, those costs are going to come down as well. It's just taking longer in the offshore because they're very busy. So I think if you are developing something in that timeframe of 2017 or so, I think you really get the full benefit of that. We're already seeing those benefits in Guyana with the rig rates that Exxon was able to get Guyana, also the seismic boat rates that they're able to get in Guyana. So you're starting to see some of that come through the value chain. But more to come on the offshore.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could just follow up on that a little bit further. I was also wondering because I'm sure you're watching, do you see anything with regard to the trying to standardize subsea approaches, things on the engineering side that might suggest that you can d
componenttext: If I could just follow up on that a little bit further. I was also wondering because I'm sure you're watching, do you see anything with regard to the trying to standardize subsea approaches, things on the engineering side that might suggest that you can drive cost down on that basis as well.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. I think there's nothing like a low price for companies to get innovative. And I know a lot of my service company, colleagues in the major oil companies are all getting the other talking about how can we better standardize as an industry t
componenttext: Yes, I think so. I think there's nothing like a low price for companies to get innovative. And I know a lot of my service company, colleagues in the major oil companies are all getting the other talking about how can we better standardize as an industry to lower the overall cost structure of the industry. Now we are doing that in our developments. For example, we're using a lot of the same things came out of Tubular Bells and Stampede, making sure there is not as much bespoke equipment that really tends to drive your cost up.
