headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Edward Westlake of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Edward Westlake of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just the market obviously with the low strip prices is very focused on outspend. Obviously, you're spending 820 on the 2 developments and when they come on stream you will get the cash flow from that, that's pretty obvious. But in terms of the next wave o
componenttext: Just the market obviously with the low strip prices is very focused on outspend. Obviously, you're spending 820 on the 2 developments and when they come on stream you will get the cash flow from that, that's pretty obvious. But in terms of the next wave of spending around Guyana or the Lower Tertiary, I'm just trying to get a sense of, are there any sort of lease terms which might force you into spending money, even if the oil price stays low? I'm trying to get a sense of, I mean, a way of asking 2017 exploration spend and development spend and maybe a trajectory into 2018.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ed. The way we look at it, and obviously as Greg said, the Guyana is an exciting opportunity for us. And you kind of laid it out. With North Malay Basin coming on stream in 2017 turning into a cash generator and then Stampede following in 2018, we d
componenttext: Sure, Ed. The way we look at it, and obviously as Greg said, the Guyana is an exciting opportunity for us. And you kind of laid it out. With North Malay Basin coming on stream in 2017 turning into a cash generator and then Stampede following in 2018, we don't really see any significant development spend coming our way for Guyana in 2017 and 2018. We see further exploration spending coming in. So the bigger development spend will be coming in fitting nicely into our portfolio as North Malay Basin and Stampede come on. So I can't really give you any specific guidance, but that's how we think about the spending going over the next couple of years.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the Bakken. Obviously, with 2 rigs, it feels like you're going to be drawing down some undeveloped -- sorry, drilled but uncompleted inventory. Maybe just an update as to -- as you roll -- if you roll the 2-rig program out into 2017
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the Bakken. Obviously, with 2 rigs, it feels like you're going to be drawing down some undeveloped -- sorry, drilled but uncompleted inventory. Maybe just an update as to -- as you roll -- if you roll the 2-rig program out into 2017, what the impact would be on Bakken production.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, Ed, with the 2-rig program, we feel pretty confident we can hold production in that range of 95,000 to 105,000 barrels a day through 2016. If you think about how that trajectory is going to unfold, though, throughout '16, it's going to start
componenttext: Yes. I think, Ed, with the 2-rig program, we feel pretty confident we can hold production in that range of 95,000 to 105,000 barrels a day through 2016. If you think about how that trajectory is going to unfold, though, throughout '16, it's going to start the year at the high end of the range and it's going to end the year at the lower end of the range. So if you fast-forward to 2017 and said I held 2 rigs through 2017, obviously, you would see some decline year-on-year. You can't hold it flat for more than a year with 2 rigs.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Cheng of Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Cheng of Barclays.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious, I mean, just 3 months ago that when you were talking about the guidance of the budget, a 4-rig program for Bakken, were you talking about 95 to 105 and now with 2 rigs. Over the last 3 months then, what may have changed that made you increas
componenttext: Just curious, I mean, just 3 months ago that when you were talking about the guidance of the budget, a 4-rig program for Bakken, were you talking about 95 to 105 and now with 2 rigs. Over the last 3 months then, what may have changed that made you increase the confidence that only 2 rigs and you actually also dropped the number of well going to be onstream next year from 100 to 80, but you keep the guidance to be the same. You said just that 3 months ago the guidance you actually feel like you could be able to reach the high end and now that you're smaller in the middle or in the low end? Just trying to understand.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Really, there's 4 factors. So first of all, the 2-rig program is really focused in the core of the core, with the higher EURs and IP rates. I think the second factor is, we've increased the stage count from 35 being our standard design to 50
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. Really, there's 4 factors. So first of all, the 2-rig program is really focused in the core of the core, with the higher EURs and IP rates. I think the second factor is, we've increased the stage count from 35 being our standard design to 50 stage fracs is our standard. And if you look at the impact of the 50-stage design, we are seeing about a 20% increase in IP 30, 60 and 90. So obviously, that's going to carry through. I think the third thing is, we're going to have increased gas and NGL capture in the plant as the Hawkeye South of the river system comes on in the third quarter of the year. And then the last is just increased drilling efficiencies. So further reductions in the spud-to-spud days. So it's really all 4 of those factors add up so you can still hold the range even with the 2-rig program.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Greg, look like the $600 million cut from the previous guidance, $300 million appears to be from the major projects because I thought previously you're talking about $1.5 billion in the major project and now it's about $1.2 billion, including the expl
componenttext: And Greg, look like the $600 million cut from the previous guidance, $300 million appears to be from the major projects because I thought previously you're talking about $1.5 billion in the major project and now it's about $1.2 billion, including the exploration or appraisal during in Guyana and Northern. Where's that $300 million has been reduced from?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, I can answer this even -- I guess maybe just in a little bit more broadly. But of that $600 million, about half of it is due to cost savings. So we are seeing further cost savings from the numbers that we had provided in October. So we're getting ab
componenttext: Paul, I can answer this even -- I guess maybe just in a little bit more broadly. But of that $600 million, about half of it is due to cost savings. So we are seeing further cost savings from the numbers that we had provided in October. So we're getting about $300 million there across. And some of it is in the development projects, some of it is in our existing assets. And then the other half like reducing to the 2 rigs in the Bakken is due to deferral of activity.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. And then, John, since you're here, Algeria, the asset sales, have you already closed before the end of the year? In other words, is the money already in your balance sheet? Or that we should expect that in the first quarter? And if it is, how much
componenttext: I see. And then, John, since you're here, Algeria, the asset sales, have you already closed before the end of the year? In other words, is the money already in your balance sheet? Or that we should expect that in the first quarter? And if it is, how much is that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the actual transaction did close right before year-end. However, we have not received the cash yet. That will be coming in the first quarter. The contract, though, is confidential. I can't give you the number on that. But it is not a significant amount
componenttext: So the actual transaction did close right before year-end. However, we have not received the cash yet. That will be coming in the first quarter. The contract, though, is confidential. I can't give you the number on that. But it is not a significant amount.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when you say not significant, does that mean less than $100 million?
componenttext: So when you say not significant, does that mean less than $100 million?

componenttextpreview: You can estimate that, Paul, yes.

componenttext: Okay. That's fine. And I just want to clarify, I have to apologize that when you speak I didn't jot it down correctly maybe. You're saying that the cash at the end of the year excluding the Bakken John mentioned is $2.3 billion? Or did I take that number wrong?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: $2.7 billion?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Asit Sen of CLSA.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Asit Sen of CLSA.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, if I may, on the cost structure. Historically, when looking at the Bakken, Greg, I think you've mentioned OpEx per barrel split of 40% variable, 60% fixed with the variable cost should benefit from lower energy component. But there
componenttext: A couple of questions, if I may, on the cost structure. Historically, when looking at the Bakken, Greg, I think you've mentioned OpEx per barrel split of 40% variable, 60% fixed with the variable cost should benefit from lower energy component. But there could be several moving parts in the fixed component, particularly as it relates to lower field personnel cost. Could you update us on that? So that's number one. Number two, on DD&A per barrel, that number should also trend lower over the medium term. Could you discuss sort of the potential trajectory? And third, on the cost structure, Stampede, first oil expected in 2018. I know the rigs have been contracted. What percent of the project cost is yet to be committed?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll try to answer all 3 of you. So the first one, you're focusing on the Bakken, but it does apply across the portfolio that we do have high -- I mean, there's a good amount of the costs that are fixed. And so obviously, we are trying to attack the
componenttext: Okay, I'll try to answer all 3 of you. So the first one, you're focusing on the Bakken, but it does apply across the portfolio that we do have high -- I mean, there's a good amount of the costs that are fixed. And so obviously, we are trying to attack the fixed cost in this low-price environment as well as the variable cost and making sure we get all the variable cost out as we reduce activity. So we have been seeing from -- let's just pick the Bakken on our cash cost per barrel. We've been seeing significant reductions like if you go back from the first quarter of 2014 through the fourth quarter of 2015, we've been seeing significant cost reductions on our cash cost per barrel. And you probably heard when I gave the 2016 guidance, we are giving guidance that our cash costs per barrel are going down in 2016, and that's with a reduction from 368,000 barrels a day pro forma production down to our 330,000 to 350,000. So we are trying to stay up with, especially in this low oil price environment, reducing fixed costs and variable cost. And so we are attacking both of them. As far as DD&A, from a trajectory standpoint, you heard from our guidance actually, our DD&A was going up in 2016, and that it's directly related to the reserves. So you heard the reserves are going down from the price revisions. So with those lower reserve amounts, that's going to increase our DD&A. As prices recover, then those reserves will come right back on the book. And so in a normal environment, what would be happening, say, in the Bakken is that as we continue to add reserves through our performance and additional drilling and now that we've got all the infrastructure spend kind of behind us, our DD&A would be going down over time. As far as Stampede, and -- I'm going to hand it back to Greg for that.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So thanks for that. Stampede, if you look at, most of the costs have already been committed, but we have taken advantage of the lower price and service environment and actually got some savings from Stampede. As we put in our capital press release ye
componenttext: Yes. So thanks for that. Stampede, if you look at, most of the costs have already been committed, but we have taken advantage of the lower price and service environment and actually got some savings from Stampede. As we put in our capital press release yesterday, we'll spend about $325 million in 2016 in Stampede.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's very helpful. And just a follow-up on Guyana. Could you talk about well costs? I know Liza was probably less than $80 million, I think you mentioned. And could you remind us of the environment, water depth, et cetera, if you could?
componenttext: Great. That's very helpful. And just a follow-up on Guyana. Could you talk about well costs? I know Liza was probably less than $80 million, I think you mentioned. And could you remind us of the environment, water depth, et cetera, if you could?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So, you're right. Liza was less than $80 million net to us. Regarding future well cost, you're going to have to refer to the operator. What I will say is, obviously, the appraisal wells will be higher cost because we're doing lots of testing and cori
componenttext: Yes. So, you're right. Liza was less than $80 million net to us. Regarding future well cost, you're going to have to refer to the operator. What I will say is, obviously, the appraisal wells will be higher cost because we're doing lots of testing and coring and the normal things that you would do in the appraisal part of the program.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from David Heikkinen of Heikkinen Energy Advisors.
componenttext: And our next question comes from David Heikkinen of Heikkinen Energy Advisors.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Have one high-level question and one kind of lower level. What do you expect your year-end 2016 cash to be?
componenttext: Have one high-level question and one kind of lower level. What do you expect your year-end 2016 cash to be?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, David, that's -- let me go through. I'll tell you how I think you should be looking at 2016. So we finished the year, as you know, with $2.7 billion of cash. And obviously, we're going to have cash flow from operations in 2016. So as we just release
componenttext: Okay, David, that's -- let me go through. I'll tell you how I think you should be looking at 2016. So we finished the year, as you know, with $2.7 billion of cash. And obviously, we're going to have cash flow from operations in 2016. So as we just released yesterday, you saw our capital spend program is estimated to be $2.4 billion in 2016. In that $2.4 billion is approximately $200 million of exploration cash spend like seismic and G&A that's part of cash flow. So we have to fund capital expenditures of $2.2 billion. And we have our dividend of approximately $285 million. Let me just round that to $300 million. So our capital and our dividend is going to be $2.5 billion in 2016. We have a cash balance at the end of '15 of $2.7 billion. So effectively, we can fund our capital program and our dividend out of our cash balance and still have $200 million left over at the end of 2016. And obviously, we'd still have the revolver undrawn. So then with that $200 million left in the cash account, David, I am going to give you some work to do here because now you have to estimate what the cash flow from operations are going to be in 2016, and that depends on your commodity price assumption. So we've given you the production guidance, the cash cost guidance and whatever cash flow from operations that you then come to, you can add to that $200 million, and that's where we'll sit. So we're in a good liquidity position coming into this year, and I think that's how you have to look at 2016.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You didn't want to fill in the blank that I was looking for, that's fair enough. On the other side, Greg, the new stage count is pretty impressive. And then you're coring up. And so just trying to get an idea of 2016 Bakken development. Do you have an ide
componenttext: You didn't want to fill in the blank that I was looking for, that's fair enough. On the other side, Greg, the new stage count is pretty impressive. And then you're coring up. And so just trying to get an idea of 2016 Bakken development. Do you have an idea of what 30, 60 and 90-day rates would be? Just round numbers would be helpful on a BOE basis.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think we have given guidance before, and we'll be at the upper end of that range, obviously, because we are in the core of the core of the Bakken. So our previous guidance will be in the high end of the range.
componenttext: No. I think we have given guidance before, and we'll be at the upper end of that range, obviously, because we are in the core of the core of the Bakken. So our previous guidance will be in the high end of the range.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I does seem like you're double dipping with the new wells and core of the core that it would have even above that range, potentially.
componenttext: Yes. I does seem like you're double dipping with the new wells and core of the core that it would have even above that range, potentially.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It will be once we have the 50-stage frac. So we need to update our guidance once we get all dialed in.
componenttext: It will be once we have the 50-stage frac. So we need to update our guidance once we get all dialed in.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. We'll roll that through to. And then just net-net of everything, what's your Bakken netback expected to be in the first quarter?
componenttext: Okay, perfect. We'll roll that through to. And then just net-net of everything, what's your Bakken netback expected to be in the first quarter?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We never really try to forecast because it's so difficult quarter-to-quarter. So in the fourth quarter, we were -- Bakken was getting between $6 and $7 under TI. And again, the economics are right now favoring more to pipe than rail.
componenttext: We never really try to forecast because it's so difficult quarter-to-quarter. So in the fourth quarter, we were -- Bakken was getting between $6 and $7 under TI. And again, the economics are right now favoring more to pipe than rail.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: About 75% of our volume now is on pipe. And the clear book differential that goes into that $6 number that John was just talking as a discount to WTI is maybe $2.50 off refineries during turnaround. That number was about $1.50 before. So there's about a $
componenttext: About 75% of our volume now is on pipe. And the clear book differential that goes into that $6 number that John was just talking as a discount to WTI is maybe $2.50 off refineries during turnaround. That number was about $1.50 before. So there's about a $1 weakness now. But as refineries come back on, we expect that to recover.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Guy Baber of Simmons and Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Guy Baber of Simmons and Company.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You all have consistently mentioned that preserving your operating capability is a key objective for the company, and that's the strategic question from me, particularly in the Bakken. Can you talk about striking that balance between cutting CapEx in rigs
componenttext: You all have consistently mentioned that preserving your operating capability is a key objective for the company, and that's the strategic question from me, particularly in the Bakken. Can you talk about striking that balance between cutting CapEx in rigs to protect the balance sheet versus preserving your capabilities so that you can respond in a timely manner when you get the appropriate oil price signal? Is that a concern for you guys with 2 rigs running? And is it a concern for you or for the industry at large in the Bakken from what you can see?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks for that question. It is striking the balance, and I think with our budgets and operating 2 rigs in the Bakken, we think we've achieved the right balance. So we're doing creative things with doubling up people and moving them over to special
componenttext: Well, thanks for that question. It is striking the balance, and I think with our budgets and operating 2 rigs in the Bakken, we think we've achieved the right balance. So we're doing creative things with doubling up people and moving them over to special assignments and all that, making sure that they're ready for the inevitable ramp-up that will come in the Bakken.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up is on the committed CapEx going forward, thinking through '17 and '18, we know that major project spending, long lead time, obligations are falling off over the next few years. But can you give us any specific indications as to
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up is on the committed CapEx going forward, thinking through '17 and '18, we know that major project spending, long lead time, obligations are falling off over the next few years. But can you give us any specific indications as to how much declines in 2017? Is the majority of the North Malay Basin CapEx in '16? You're not going to have that spending commitment in '17 or is that more of an '18 event? Just trying to get a better sense there, as I think it would help us better appreciate and understand the evolution of the free cash flow profile in a flat oil price environment, which is an important consideration.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So from a commitment standpoint, what we'd be looking at over the next couple of years is to complete North Malay Basin, complete Stampede and, obviously, continue the exploration that we have going on, in particular in Guyana. So in 2017, North Mal
componenttext: Sure. So from a commitment standpoint, what we'd be looking at over the next couple of years is to complete North Malay Basin, complete Stampede and, obviously, continue the exploration that we have going on, in particular in Guyana. So in 2017, North Malay Basin will be coming online. So we have $375 million in the budget this year that is essentially reducing our free cash flow by that $375 million. Now we don't have exactly what the budget will be for North Malay Basin next year as far as pure capital, but it will be considerably lower than the $375 million. But again, no matter what that number is, it will be generating free cash flow. So as you look to 2017, we will get an improvement of free cash flow just related to North Malay Basin of $375 million. And then, again, you'd follow on that with Stampede, so you have $325 million this year not generating free cash flow. Again, we don't have the budget set for '17. I don't expect it to be that different in '17 as you move forward with Stampede. And so it won't be until '18 that you'll turn around that $325 million of free cash flow.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Evan Calio of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Evan Calio of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sort of a follow-up to prior cash question. What do you guys consider the minimum operating cash limits on the balance sheet? And I realize on most of the math that you supplied before on the call, you currently support the dividend given your balance she
componenttext: Sort of a follow-up to prior cash question. What do you guys consider the minimum operating cash limits on the balance sheet? And I realize on most of the math that you supplied before on the call, you currently support the dividend given your balance sheet strength. How do you consider the dividend strategy in the context of a constrained cash flow environment and the amount of the breadth of longer-term investment opportunities that you have as you navigate towards '16?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Evan. So again, as we drill[ph] through that, I mean, we are just in a good position relative to our competition with this $2.7 billion of cash. We don't need any cash flow from operations to fund our capital program, as I mentioned, of 2.2  plus th
componenttext: Sure, Evan. So again, as we drill[ph] through that, I mean, we are just in a good position relative to our competition with this $2.7 billion of cash. We don't need any cash flow from operations to fund our capital program, as I mentioned, of 2.2  plus the dividend, if I round up to $300 million. So we can fund that completely out of our cash account and have $200 million left over in there. And there will be, if you want to see the minimum level, you're somewhere around that, say, the $200 million that you want to at least keep in our system between the U.S. and internationally. But again, we don't even need any cash flow from operations, just to repeat that, to fund the capital or dividend. So anything, again, as your estimate for cash flow from operations will just get added do that cash balance, so we won't be near this any minimum levels as it relates to cash.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. A couple of smaller follow-up items. Can you give a cost or EUR uplift from the 50-stage Bakken completions versus the 35-stage design?
componenttext: That makes sense. A couple of smaller follow-up items. Can you give a cost or EUR uplift from the 50-stage Bakken completions versus the 35-stage design?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you look at 2015, particularly at the back half of the year when we had a lot of 50 stagers coming online, we were at the top end of our guidance range. So the 550 to 650, we were at the very top end of that. We averaged 650 for the whole year
componenttext: Yes. So if you look at 2015, particularly at the back half of the year when we had a lot of 50 stagers coming online, we were at the top end of our guidance range. So the 550 to 650, we were at the very top end of that. We averaged 650 for the whole year in 2015. And as we drill on the core of the core next year and do the 50-stage fracs, we expect to be in the high 600 to the mid-700 range. So you're seeing that uplift. Also on the IP rates, you could see a similar sort of effect. I mean, the range we've given on IP rates is 800 to 950. And obviously, with the 50-stage fracs on the IP rates, you're going to be up there. One other point I want to make about the well cost in the Bakken, the well cost for the fourth quarter averaged $5.1 million per well, which is about a 28% reduction from the year ago and a 4% reduction from Q3. Again, that lean manufacturing machine just continuing to work. We said that we expect cost next year to be broadly flat at that $5 million to $5.1 million per well level. But of course, that math, the significant amount of ongoing improvement because embedded in that number of the $5.1 million is a 40% increase in stage count. So we expect to fully offset that increase in cost due to the higher stage count with continued lean manufacturing gains. So again, a 20% uplift in production for basically the same cost is what you have this year. So obviously, that's going to be good for returns.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I guess a similar spud-to-spud, I think, an 18 day or is that -- what that number is we should assume?
componenttext: And then I guess a similar spud-to-spud, I think, an 18 day or is that -- what that number is we should assume?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It will improve again next year. I mean, this year, we averaged about 22 wells per rig during the year. That's going to increase to, say, 24 or so next year.
componenttext: Yes. It will improve again next year. I mean, this year, we averaged about 22 wells per rig during the year. That's going to increase to, say, 24 or so next year.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And lastly for me, a small one. If you can share what you booked on North Malay expansion in 2016? Just want to know how much of that project value is potentially reflected in your reserve numbers?
componenttext: Great. And lastly for me, a small one. If you can share what you booked on North Malay expansion in 2016? Just want to know how much of that project value is potentially reflected in your reserve numbers?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that was not -- there was no addition to our reserves in 2015 for the North Malay Basin expansion.
componenttext: No, that was not -- there was no addition to our reserves in 2015 for the North Malay Basin expansion.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a number of what that -- what's in there? What's in your -- What you booked or what you have as spuds there?
componenttext: Can you give us a number of what that -- what's in there? What's in your -- What you booked or what you have as spuds there?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So what we have for North Malay Basin, and this is kind if you get to this unique reserve accounting rules, because we don't -- during 2015, we did not have a significant amount of wells in the ground that we could book proved reserves on. And as Gr
componenttext: Okay. So what we have for North Malay Basin, and this is kind if you get to this unique reserve accounting rules, because we don't -- during 2015, we did not have a significant amount of wells in the ground that we could book proved reserves on. And as Greg mentioned, we started the drilling program more now kicking it off in '16 to drill up the reservoirs. We didn't have that significant of reserves, say, initially. And then when you run it through the reserve accounting requirements, because those proved reserves are low compared to the gas sale contract, we can't book the reserves here in 2015. So what will happen is as Greg's team just drills out in 2016, we'll actually begin booking the reserves at North Malay Basin.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to follow up on some of the Guyana questions. You mentioned that the Early Production System depends on the appraisal program. Can you talk more specifically about what you expect to learn with the Liza #2 and then the same kind of question for how
componenttext: Wanted to follow up on some of the Guyana questions. You mentioned that the Early Production System depends on the appraisal program. Can you talk more specifically about what you expect to learn with the Liza #2 and then the same kind of question for how the next 3 wells that you're drilling and planning this year differ and what the learnings could be from those wells as well?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, so let's talk about Liza appraisal first. I mean, we want to get a dynamic test. That will tell us about potential compartmentalization in Liza. We also want to find where the contact is. So that will be the primary 2 objectives of the appra
componenttext: Yes, I think, so let's talk about Liza appraisal first. I mean, we want to get a dynamic test. That will tell us about potential compartmentalization in Liza. We also want to find where the contact is. So that will be the primary 2 objectives of the appraisal wells in Liza. The exploration wells are basically -- the objective there is to figure out what we're seeing on seismic, is that replicable in other areas of the block because we have a lot of look-alikes on seismic. So we want to get a well or 2, and a couple of the other things and see what running room we have on the block. We think there's a lot, but obviously you'll need some more wells to figure that out.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then my follow-up is with regards to M&A. You'd mentioned really going back a year valuations never really looked attractive from a consolidation perspective. And I wondered, a, if you can kind of comment on how those look now? And then, b, rec
componenttext: Great. And then my follow-up is with regards to M&A. You'd mentioned really going back a year valuations never really looked attractive from a consolidation perspective. And I wondered, a, if you can kind of comment on how those look now? And then, b, recognizing that preserving balance sheet is one of your key objectives, is the opportunities that you now see at Guyana at Sicily still meaningful that it reduces your interest level in even considering fuel consolidation?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look. Fair question on M&A. We always look at the outside to see if there are opportunities that will make our portfolio stronger, improve our economic opportunities for investment and also not sacrifice our balance sheet strength. And while values have c
componenttext: Look. Fair question on M&A. We always look at the outside to see if there are opportunities that will make our portfolio stronger, improve our economic opportunities for investment and also not sacrifice our balance sheet strength. And while values have come down, just to reiterate, while our priority is, first and foremost, the strength of our balance sheet and obviously the company's really well positioned with our $2.7 billion of cash at the end of the year, one of the strongest balance sheets and liquidity positions among our peers, we further strengthened that balance sheet by the further reduction in our spending for 2016 to the $2.4 billion number we're talking about. It's about value, not volume. So the whole focus is the balance sheet. And yet at the same time, it's very important that the company, we are in a long-term business, everybody's thinking short-term, that we invest for future growth on a disciplined and focused basis and we feel we're extremely well positioned with the growth options that we have both in North Malay Basin and Stampede, but also obviously Guyana, that the company is going to benefit quite a bit and our shareholders as well as oil prices recover ultimately with these growth options that we've already assembled. So we feel pretty good about what we've already captured, and therefore, M&A is very low on the priority list.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Roger Read of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Roger Read of Wells Fargo.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess 2 questions. One on the Bakken in terms of the efficiencies. Do you continue to do testing in this environment or with the 2-well program strictly we should think about it as development and maybe putting further efficiencies on a hold for now? Or
componenttext: I guess 2 questions. One on the Bakken in terms of the efficiencies. Do you continue to do testing in this environment or with the 2-well program strictly we should think about it as development and maybe putting further efficiencies on a hold for now? Or as a drive for further efficiencies?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think part of lean manufacturing is every day you look for the next improvement. So in terms of piloting, though, I think we've done the infills, 9/8 been very successful, 50-stage fracs been very successful. So those now will become our standard de
componenttext: No. I think part of lean manufacturing is every day you look for the next improvement. So in terms of piloting, though, I think we've done the infills, 9/8 been very successful, 50-stage fracs been very successful. So those now will become our standard design, obviously, in the core of the core. But every day we're looking for the next improvement, right. So that drive will continue. That will go on, and we're constantly trying to improve everything across our business there, and that's all part of the lean manufacturing philosophy.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as you think about, and you'd mentioned earlier in the beginning of the call, opportunities in the deepwater, you've been able to get in. Others are struggling on the cash flow side. As you look at some of those partners and you think about
componenttext: Okay. And then as you think about, and you'd mentioned earlier in the beginning of the call, opportunities in the deepwater, you've been able to get in. Others are struggling on the cash flow side. As you look at some of those partners and you think about taking these projects for either an appraisal well or ultimately full development if it works out that way, what sort of, I guess, roadblocks may we run into where partners simply don't want to fund those next steps? And how do we -- it's been a long time since we've had a downturn like this. How should we think about the workout of that process over time?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, if you think about what we're in currently, so Sicily, clearly, Chevron wants to move forward, we're aligned with that in the appraisal. ConocoPhillips, obviously, moved forward with Melmar. Guyana moving forward with Exxon. Nova Scotia,
componenttext: Well, certainly, if you think about what we're in currently, so Sicily, clearly, Chevron wants to move forward, we're aligned with that in the appraisal. ConocoPhillips, obviously, moved forward with Melmar. Guyana moving forward with Exxon. Nova Scotia, BP, moving forward. So we don't really see any partner risk of people not wanting to move forward. Regarding your question in the opportunity space, there is a lot of opportunity out there, very good prospects, very low entry cost, but we're going to be extremely disciplined. And it's going to have to be really good in order for us to even consider adding it to the mix. And Melmar was one example of something that was very good, and we made the decision to get in. But we're going to be extremely disciplined and very selective on how we do that.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jeffrey Campbell of Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeffrey Campbell of Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first question I wanted to ask was, did I understand correctly that the reduced spending in North Malay and Stampede was largely on cost saving? And if so, can you indicate where what sort of savings we're talking about? And also was I correct that th
componenttext: The first question I wanted to ask was, did I understand correctly that the reduced spending in North Malay and Stampede was largely on cost saving? And if so, can you indicate where what sort of savings we're talking about? And also was I correct that the time lines to first oil are intact?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the time lines to first oil are intact. When I was talking about cost savings, it was across the portfolio. We had a mix of that $600 million, where kind of half of it was cost savings and half of it was deferment of activity. So there is
componenttext: I'll start with the time lines to first oil are intact. When I was talking about cost savings, it was across the portfolio. We had a mix of that $600 million, where kind of half of it was cost savings and half of it was deferment of activity. So there is a mix on North Malay Basin and Stampede. It's not like that was all cost savings.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then thinking about -- staying on the theme of cost savings in the offshore. I was just wondering, can you comment broadly about your current view of industry efforts to reduce offshore development costs? And specifically, I'm thinking of back w
componenttext: Okay. And then thinking about -- staying on the theme of cost savings in the offshore. I was just wondering, can you comment broadly about your current view of industry efforts to reduce offshore development costs? And specifically, I'm thinking of back when you said that Guyana looked great at $80 a barrel, but not as much at lower oil prices. Other than waiting for a higher future oil price, do you see developments unfolding that can make a play like Guyana better able to attract capital in a better but still moderate oil price environment?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. I mean if you look at cost reductions, if you look at the onshore, I would say the progression of cost reductions in the onshore has been much more rapid than the offshore. For very practical reasons, the offshore fleet, there's still a l
componenttext: Yes, I think so. I mean if you look at cost reductions, if you look at the onshore, I would say the progression of cost reductions in the onshore has been much more rapid than the offshore. For very practical reasons, the offshore fleet, there's still a lot of rigs on contract at relatively high prices. The yards are full, still full, as you kind of look around the globe. So we see that really opening up though. As rigs come off contract in the offshore, as yards become not at capacity, those costs are going to come down as well. It's just taking longer in the offshore because they're very busy. So I think if you are developing something in that time frame of 2017 or so, I think you really get the full benefit of that. We're already seeing those benefits in Guyana with the rig rates that Exxon was able to get in Guyana, also the seismic boat rates that they were able to get in Guyana. So you're starting to see some of that come through the value chain. But more to come on the offshore.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could just follow up on that a little bit further. I was also wondering because I'm sure you're watching, do you see anything with regard to trends like trying to standardize subsea approaches, things on the engineering side that might suggest that y
componenttext: If I could just follow up on that a little bit further. I was also wondering because I'm sure you're watching, do you see anything with regard to trends like trying to standardize subsea approaches, things on the engineering side that might suggest that you can drive cost down on that basis as well?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. I think there's nothing like a low price for companies to get innovative. And I know a lot of my service company colleagues in the major oil companies are all getting together, talking about how can we better standardize as an industry to
componenttext: Yes, I think so. I think there's nothing like a low price for companies to get innovative. And I know a lot of my service company colleagues in the major oil companies are all getting together, talking about how can we better standardize as an industry to lower the overall cost structure of the industry. We are doing that in our developments. For example, we're using a lot of the same things that came out of Tubular Bells and Stampede, making sure there is not as much bespoke equipment that really tends to drive your cost up.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov of Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov of Raymond James.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You addressed the M&A question from the buy side. I -- maybe I'll try it from the sell side. You've been a net seller of assets for more than 3 years now. Has that pretty much run its course with the Algeria deal? Or are you still looking to monetize addi
componenttext: You addressed the M&A question from the buy side. I -- maybe I'll try it from the sell side. You've been a net seller of assets for more than 3 years now. Has that pretty much run its course with the Algeria deal? Or are you still looking to monetize additional assets other than, of course, the Bakken MLP?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Fair question. We will always look to optimize our portfolio in the normal course of business. So we will continue to take that approach.
componenttext: Yes. Fair question. We will always look to optimize our portfolio in the normal course of business. So we will continue to take that approach.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any particular geographies that come to mind?
componenttext: Any particular geographies that come to mind?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Philips Johnston of Capital One.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Philips Johnston of Capital One.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on Ed's question earlier on the declines in the Bakken if we assume you continue to run 2 rigs throughout this year and next. Can you give us an update on what sort of cushion you have on your MVCs, if we just assume your operating produc
componenttext: Just a follow-up on Ed's question earlier on the declines in the Bakken if we assume you continue to run 2 rigs throughout this year and next. Can you give us an update on what sort of cushion you have on your MVCs, if we just assume your operating production continues to decline and if we assume production from other operators also declines in the basin? You've got some incremental volumes, I think, coming into the Hawkeye system, which should sort of help offset that. But can you just give us an update on your latest thinking there and whether or not that's something that we should be concerned about?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, no, I guess is the answer on an overall basis. I just wanted to let you know, in our supplement that is being posted, we actually have the 2016 minimum volume commitments there. Maybe I can just walk you through that. From a processing stand
componenttext: First of all, no, I guess is the answer on an overall basis. I just wanted to let you know, in our supplement that is being posted, we actually have the 2016 minimum volume commitments there. Maybe I can just walk you through that. From a processing standpoint, the '16 commitment is 186 million scufs a day. In the fourth quarter, we were right at that 186. And as I mentioned earlier, we had unplanned downtime. In the third quarter, we were up at 210 and the second quarter 202. Don't see any issues with that with the 2-rig program. From the pipeline standpoint, we gathered 50,000 barrels of oil per day and the commitment is 45,000 in '16. And gas gathering was 198 in the fourth quarter and the minimum vol is 189. Do not see an issue there. So the one small thing that we may see and we think it's under $10 million, say, to us is going to be on our logistics on the rail. Because as we mentioned earlier, the economics now are favoring more to the pipeline, but obviously that can change. So just from -- in the fourth quarter, our terminal throughput was 62,000 barrels of oil per day. The minimum volume commitment is 73,000. Back in the second quarter, we had 82,000 going through that terminal. But as far as the rail terminal crude loading, we were at 42,000 barrels a day. The minimum volume commitment is 38,000. And for rail services, it's 43,000 barrels a day for the minimum volume commitment and the fourth quarter was at 43,000. So bottom line, we do not expect any real issues from the minimum volume standpoint and the buildout from the Hawkeye south of the river will begin to add throughput back into the system for us.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shannon. Good morning, everyone, and than you for participating in our first quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projections
componenttext:
Thank you, Shannon. Good morning, everyone, and than you for participating in our first quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. 
Today's conference call contains projections and other forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. These statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from those expressed or implied in such statements. These risks include those set forth in the section of Hess' annual and quarterly reports filed with the SEC. 
Also on today's conference call, we may discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation of the differences between these non-GAAP financial measures and the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures can be found in the supplemental information provided on our website. 
With me today are John Hess, Chief Executive Officer; Greg Hill, Chief Operating Officer; and John Rielly, Chief Financial Officer. I'll now turn the call over to John Hess

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay. Welcome to our first quarter conference call. I will provide an update on the steps we are taking to manage in the low price oil price environment and review some of the highlights from the quarter. Greg Hill will then discuss our operatin
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay. Welcome to our first quarter conference call. I will provide an update on the steps we are taking to manage in the low price oil price environment and review some of the highlights from the quarter. Greg Hill will then discuss our operating performance, and John Rielly will review our financial results. 
Our strategy in this lower-for-longer price environment is guided by 3 principles: Preserve our balance sheet, preserve our operating capabilities and preserve our growth options. 
To preserve our balance sheet, on February 4, we successfully executed a capital raise of $1.6 billion through common and mandatory convertible preferred stock offerings. These proceeds will keep our strong balance sheet strong in the low oil price environment and provide the financial flexibility to continue to invest in our growth projects, north Malay Basin in the Gulf of Thailand, Stampede in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico and exploration offshore Guyana. 
Further to preserving the strength of our balance sheet, in January, we announced our 2016 capital and exploratory budget of $2.4 billion, 40% below 2015 levels. Our focus remains on value, not volume, and we do not believe that accelerating production in the current oil price environment makes sense. Rather, we have reduced activity levels across our producing portfolio, both onshore and offshore. Our Bakken rig count will be reduced from 3 rigs currently to 2 rigs during the third quarter and is expected to remain at this level until the WTI price is closer to $60 per barrel. In the Utica, our 1 drilling rig was released in March and no further drilling is planned this year. Offshore, we continue the drilling break in Norway and Equatorial Guinea and the rig at Sourth Arne in Denmark is set to be released in the second quarter.
In terms of our operating capabilities, we are delivering industry-leading performance, as confirmed by third-party benchmarks, both in unconventionals and offshore drilling and development. Our resilient portfolio is linked to our top quartile operating capabilities and is balanced between unconventionals and offshore, providing an attractive mix of short cycle and long cycle investment opportunities. This balanced portfolio also casts a wider net for future long-term growth options. 
Our portfolio is leveraged to oil and liquids, with industry-leading cash margins and advantaged tax positions in the U.S. and Norway that will accelerate cash flow growth as oil prices improve. 
In terms of our growth opportunities we have, leading positions in the Bakken and Utica shale plays; new field startups North Malay Basin and Stampede, which, combined, are expected to add 35,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day of new production over the next 2 years and, by 2018, will become material cash generators; and recent exploration success in Guyana that has the potential to provide significant long-term value creation and growth.
Turning to our financial results. In the first quarter of 2016, we posted a net loss of $509 million or $1.72 per share compared to an adjusted net loss of $0.98 per share in the year-ago quarter. Compared to the first quarter of 2015, our financial results were negatively impacted by lower crude oil and natural gas selling prices and higher exploration expense, which more than offset the positive impacts of lower cash costs and DD&A.
While low crude oil prices significantly impacted our first quarter financial results, we delivered strong operational performance. Net production was at the high end of our guidance range, averaging 350,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day compared to net production of 355,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the year-ago quarter pro forma for last year's sale of our assets in Algeria. Net production from the Bakken averaged 111,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the first quarter of 2016, above our guidance range. Our Bakken team reduced drilling and completion costs 25% from the year-ago quarter to an average of $5.1 million per well.
In summary, with our strong balance sheet, oil-leveraged portfolio and attractive growth opportunities, we believe the company is well positioned to deliver strong cash flow growth and long-term value as oil prices recover. I will now turn the call over to Greg for an operational update

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I'd like to provide an update on our progress in 2016 as we continue to execute our E&P strategy. Starting with production. In the first quarter, we averaged 350,000 net barrels of oil equivalent per day, at the top end of our guidance ran
componenttext:
Thanks, John. I'd like to provide an update on our progress in 2016 as we continue to execute our E&P strategy. 
Starting with production. In the first quarter, we averaged 350,000 net barrels of oil equivalent per day, at the top end of our guidance range of 340,000 to 350,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day and, once again, reflecting strong operating performance across our portfolio. In the second quarter, we expect net production to average between 320,000 and 325,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, reflecting planned maintenance downtime at Valhall and several of our deepwater Gulf of Mexico fields. As usual, we will provide an update to our full year production guidance on our midyear call in July.
Turning to operations and beginning with the Bakken. Our lean manufacturing approach has once again enabled us to deliver outstanding performance from one of the best core of the core positions in the play where we retain a substantial drilling inventory with attractive economics even at current prices. Despite reducing our Bakken rig count to an average of 4 rigs in the first quarter 2016 from 12 rigs in the year-ago quarter, net production from the Bakken averaged 111,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the first quarter compared to 108,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the year-ago quarter. 
During the first quarter, we drilled 19 wells and brought 31 new wells online. This compares to the year-ago quarter when we drilled 60 wells and brought 70 wells online. We currently plan to maintain a 3-rig program through the second quarter, to release 1 rig during the third quarter and operate 2 rigs for the remainder of the year.
In 2016, we now expect to drill 62 wells and bring 87 new wells online. This compares to last year when we drilled 182 wells and brought 219 wells online. 
In the first quarter, our average drilling and completion costs is $5.1 million per well. We expect to be able to maintain this cost level over 2016 even as we transition from our previous 35-stage completion design to our new standard 50-stage completion design. This higher stage count is expected to deliver a 15% to 20% increase in initial production rates. And with our rigs focused in the core of the play, we expect our estimated ultimate recovery per well to move toward 1 million barrels of oil equivalent in the latter part of 2016. We also continue to successfully execute our 17 well per DSU spacing pilots and still see the majority of the wells performing in line with type curves and with minimal interference. The combination of both higher overall type curve performance and higher density well spacing has allowed us to increase our estimated ultimate recovery from the Bakken from our previous estimate of 1.4 billion barrels of oil equivalent to 1.6 billion barrels of oil equivalent. For the second quarter, we forecast net Bakken production to average between 100,000 and 110,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day.
Moving to the Utica. In the first quarter, the joint venture drilled 6 wells and brought 9 wells on production. Net production for the first quarter averaged 29,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day compared to 17,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the year-ago quarter. Similar to our Bakken position, our Utica acreage is largely held by production, which allows us to reduce activity in the short term while preserving optionality and longer-term upside. While we benefit from our acreage being in the core of the play in a low 5% [indiscernible], we released the 1 rig we had operating in the play in early March. As a result of applying our distinctive lean manufacturing approach, over the past several years we have been able to reduce our drilling cost per foot by approximately 75% and our completion cost per stage by approximately 50% while at the same time drilling some of the longest laterals in the play. 
We plan to run the assets for cash in 2016 and to resume drilling following a sustained recovery in commodity prices and further third-party infrastructure buildout, which will reduce the currently wide basin differentials.
Now turning to the offshore. At the Tubular Bells Field in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, in which Hess holds a 57.1% working interest and is operator, net production averaged 10,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the first quarter. During the quarter, we conducted the remediation work highlighted in our fourth quarter call, completing asset jobs at 2 wells. We are now moving the rig to replace a defective subsurface valve that failed to open. This is the second failure of this type in the field, and we are working with the supplier to understand the root causes of the manufacturing feedback.
In the second quarter, we have an extended shutdown scheduled to tie back nobles Gunflint field to the William zone host facility, and we plan to spud a fifth producing well in the field. 
In early April, we also completed our first water injection well, and we expect to commence injection in the third quarter.
In Norway, at BP-operated Valhall Field, in which Hess has a 64% interest, net production averaged 30,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the first quarter. The operator plans to commence an extended shutdown in the second quarter due to required maintenance work at the ConocoPhillips operated Ekofisk field. 
At the South Arne Field in Denmark, which Hess operates with a 61.5% interest, we have completed the current phase of development drilling and do not plan to drill any additional wells in 2016. Net production averaged 14,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day over the quarter.
At the Malaysia/Thailand Joint Development Area in the Gulf of Thailand, in which Hess has a 50% interest, work continues on the booster compression project, which remains on schedule for completion in the third quarter. Net production averaged 230 million cubic feet per day in the first quarter.
Moving to developments. At North Malay Basin in the Gulf of Thailand, in which Hess holds a 50% interest and is operator, progress continues on full field development. 6 out of 11 developed wells have now been drilled, and drilling results to date are better than expected. Net production from the Early Production System averaged 30 million cubic feet per day in the first quarter. Following completion of full field development in 2017, net production is planned to increase to approximately 165 million cubic feet per day. 
At the Stampede development in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, in which Hess holds a 25% working interest and is operator, we successfully floated the top sites main deck onto the production deck, set the whole structure into the offshore floating dock and installed the oil export line. Drilling operations are underway on the first production well, and first oil remains on schedule for 2018.
Moving to exploration. In the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, the Chevron-operated Sicily-2 well, in which Hess holds a 25% working interest, reached its target depth and results are currently being evaluated. 
Also in the Gulf of Mexico, the ConocoPhillips-operated Melmar well, in which Hess has a 35% working interest, reached target depth in the early April and logging operations are now complete. The well results are still being evaluated, but as noncommercial quantities of oil were encountered at the current location, the well was expensed in the quarter. 
In Guyana, in the Stabroek Block, in which Hess holds a 30% interest, the operator, Esso Exploration and Production Guyana Limited, spud the Liza #2 well in February. This well is designed to further evaluate the significant Liza oil discovery and will include an extended drill steam test. We expect the operator to complete operations on the Liza-2 well late in the second quarter. Following the Liza-2 well, the operator intends to move the rig to test a separate prospect located approximately 25 miles Northwest of Liza. We remain excited about the opportunity set on this block, which we believe could be material to our company.
In closing, we have maintained excellent execution and delivery across our portfolio. We believe that our focus on preserving the strength of our balance sheet, while also preserving our top quartile capabilities and growth options, is the right strategy. I will now turn the call over to John Rielly.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. In my remarks today, I will compare results from the first quarter of 2016 to the fourth quarter of 2015. In the first quarter of 2016, we reported a net loss of $509 million compared with an adjusted net loss of $396 million in the previo
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. In my remarks today, I will compare results from the first quarter of 2016 to the fourth quarter of 2015. 
In the first quarter of 2016, we reported a net loss of $509 million compared with an adjusted net loss of $396 million in the previous quarter that excludes a net charge of $1,425,000,000.
Turning to exploration and production. E&P incurred a net loss of $451 million in the first quarter of 2016 compared to an adjusted net loss of $328 million in the fourth quarter of 2015. That excludes net charges totaling $1,385,000,000. 
The changes in the after-tax components of adjusted results for E&P between the first quarter of 2016 and the fourth quarter of 2015 were as follows: Lower realized selling prices reduced results by $187 million. Lower sales volumes reduced results by $4 million. Lower cash operating costs improved results by $28 million. Lowe DD&A expense improved results by $71 million. Higher exploration expenses reduced results by $18 million. All other items net to a decrease in results of $13 million for an overall increase in the first quarter net loss of $123 million.
In the first quarter, our E&P operations were overlifted compared with production by approximately 500,000 barrels which did not have a material impact on first quarter results. 
The E&P effective income tax rate was a benefit of 41% for the first quarter of 2016 compared with a benefit of 38% in the fourth quarter, excluding items affecting comparability.
Turning to midstream. First quarter net income of $14 million increased from $11 million in the previous quarter, primarily due to lower operating costs. Bakken Midstream EBITDA, excluding the noncontrolling interest, amounted to $70 million in the first quarter of 2016 compared to $67 million in the previous quarter.
Turning to Corporate and interest. After-tax Corporate and interest expenses were $72 million in the first quarter of 2016 compared to $79 million in the fourth quarter of 2015, which excludes net charges totaling $32 million. The reduction resulted from lower professional fees and general and administrative costs.
Turning to cash flow. Net cash provided by operating activities before changes in working capital was $148 million. A net decrease in cash resulting from changes in working capital was $208 million. Additions to property, plant and equipment were $620 million. Net debt repayments were $12 million. Net proceeds from the issuance of common and preferred stock were $1,644,000,000. Common stock dividends paid were $80 million. Other net amounted to a use of cash of $31 million, resulting in a net increase in cash and cash equivalents in the first quarter of $841 million.
Turning to our financial position. We had approximately $3.6 billion of cash and cash equivalents at March 31, 2016 and total liquidity, including available committed credit facilities of approximately $8.3 billion. Excluding Bakken Midstream, total debt was $5.9 billion at March of 31, 2016, and our debt-to-capitalization ratio was 23.1%.
Now turning to second quarter guidance. For E&P, we project cash cost for E&P operations to be in the range of $16.50 to $17.50 per barrel of oil equivalent, reflecting lower production and higher maintenance costs from the planned offshore facility shutdowns. 
DD&A per barrel of oil equivalent is forecast to be $26.50 to $27.50 per barrel, resulting in projected total E&P unit operating cost of $43 to $45 per barrel in the second quarter of 2016.
The Bakken midstream tariff expense is expected to be $3.75 to $3.85 per barrel of oil equivalent for the second quarter of 2016, while exploration expenses, excluding dry-hole costs, are expected to be in the range of $70 million to $80 million. 
The E&P effective tax rate is expected to be a deferred tax benefit in the range of 42% to 46% for the second quarter. 
For Midstream, we estimate net income attributable to Hess from the Bakken Midstream segment, which reflects our 50% ownership, to be in the range of $10 million to $15 million in the second quarter. 
For Corporate and interest, we expect Corporate expenses, net of taxes, to be in the range of $25 million to $30 million, and interest expense to be in the range of $50 million to $55 million in the second quarter of 2016. 
This concludes my remarks. We will be happy to answer any questions. I will now turn the call over to the operator.

componenttext: If you look at the majority of the wells that we brought on in the first quarter of this year, the majority were 35-stage fracs. headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Doug, I'll start with the differentials. There was something unusual just from -- in the first quarter and it had to do just with our timing of lift. So there's 2 aspects of why our differentials widened. So with the timing, actually, we produced ab
componenttext: Okay, Doug, I'll start with the differentials. There was something unusual just from -- in the first quarter and it had to do just with our timing of lift. So there's 2 aspects of why our differentials widened. So with the timing, actually, we produced about approximately 75,000 barrels a day of oil internationally, but our liftings were heavily in January and February. We actually lifted about 89,000 barrels a day in January and 130,000 barrels a day in February. And March liftings were only 19,000. So obviously, we lifted more just timing wise when oil prices were lower in the quarter. And so that had an impact on our differentials. The other thing that did a true weakening was on the West African crude, not just ours, but in general, West African crudes were kind of the differential widened about $1, and that did happen with our liftings as well in the quarter.

componenttext: Yes. Doug, this is Greg. That was primarily just a weather-related operational issue in January. It had to do with complying with Reid vapor pressure requirements in the field. That caused to shut in some oil production. So if you look at kind of oil in January, it was actually down around 69. But that completely reversed itself in February, March, and it was 75,000 barrels a day for the month of February and March. So that came back up. So it was just a temporary issue in January.

componenttext: Doug, the only other thing I'll add to that with the wells, we are, it is our focus this year with our midstream infrastructure, we are out gathering more gas.
