componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Cheng of Barclays.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I think in the past, you guys have talked about this, sustaining Capex about $1.5 billion. IS that still the number or that number has changed?
componenttext: John, I think in the past, you guys have talked about this, sustaining Capex about $1.5 billion. IS that still the number or that number has changed?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we look at -- if you're asking like a sustainable CapEx level that we talked about for maintaining flat production, if you look at right now, we're around, as John mentioned earlier, $2 billion of capital this year. With that, we have North Malay Basin
componenttext: So we look at -- if you're asking like a sustainable CapEx level that we talked about for maintaining flat production, if you look at right now, we're around, as John mentioned earlier, $2 billion of capital this year. With that, we have North Malay Basin and Stampede coming online and that 35,000 barrels a day come online in 2018. So when that comes online, from our production levels that we have, we'll basically be able to keep our production levels flat from, maybe some slight growth when you're putting it in and spending that $2 billion. So I would say it's in a range, right? You can do this like $1.75 billion to $2.4 billion range of capital, all depending on your FMD cost that you have in your portfolio for us at our current production levels. So we're producing 120 million, 130 million barrels a year. So just use an FMD and cost in that range can get you that general type of CapEx level. Now we can certainly lower that CapEx level and maintain that kind of cash flow in the [indiscernible] if we wanted to do that, but that would affect your long-term production growth.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I understand. I guess, from mix view, what's your minimum spending for Stampede [ph] and North Malay going to be?
componenttext: Sure, I understand. I guess, from mix view, what's your minimum spending for Stampede [ph] and North Malay going to be?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. so we went into the year basically with about 700 million on both of these projects as a budget. 375 on North Malay Basin, 325 on Stampede. The North Malay Basin number will come down, so we'll update you and give you more specific number in January
componenttext: Sure. so we went into the year basically with about 700 million on both of these projects as a budget. 375 on North Malay Basin, 325 on Stampede. The North Malay Basin number will come down, so we'll update you and give you more specific number in January. But it's going to come down because as we said, it's going to start production in the third quarter. Now the Stampede number will go up because we have a second drilling rig coming into the field in January. And then once again, as we put our capital budget together in January, we'll update you on the specific numbers.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: But combined, you're still probably pretty close to about 700  then, right? Because as you go down, you're not probably affected by the increase in Stampede, I presume?
componenttext: But combined, you're still probably pretty close to about 700  then, right? Because as you go down, you're not probably affected by the increase in Stampede, I presume?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. You don't want to be specific, but we're going to be in that range again just because that will be an increase in Stampede and the reduction on North Malay Basin. But obviously, once the third quarter starts, we're the beginning to get cash flow at
componenttext: Right. You don't want to be specific, but we're going to be in that range again just because that will be an increase in Stampede and the reduction on North Malay Basin. But obviously, once the third quarter starts, we're the beginning to get cash flow at the North Malay Basin, and that's really the key again for us is the 35,000 barrels a day comes in, in 2018 and they go from using $700 million of cash to generating cash. So we're generating that big cash flow inflection point for us coming in 2018 on.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And just curious, in the $1.75 billion to $2.4 [ph] billion, whatever that number then end up based on the 2017 budget, but in the past, given -- particularly, given now that you have no sizable debt maturity until 2027, [ph] on a going-forward bas
componenttext: Right. And just curious, in the $1.75 billion to $2.4 [ph] billion, whatever that number then end up based on the 2017 budget, but in the past, given -- particularly, given now that you have no sizable debt maturity until 2027, [ph] on a going-forward basis, your oil price lies in your cash flow from operations start to be in excess of that level, should we assume your [indiscernible] one a cash flow neutral model. So whatever you take increase in the cash flow exceeding that level will get popped back into the exploration or into the CapEx? Or that is not a totally good assumption?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It goes back to what John has a said earlier, right? There's a balance of how we would use the additional cash flow. So with our portfolio, you know we're oil weighted, so a $1 move in oil prices give us an annual basis approximately $70 million of additi
componenttext: It goes back to what John has a said earlier, right? There's a balance of how we would use the additional cash flow. So with our portfolio, you know we're oil weighted, so a $1 move in oil prices give us an annual basis approximately $70 million of additional cash flow. So we are in that position to really with that recovery in oil prices to benefit from it. So what we'll then do is look at our short, our medium term, our long-term growth options that we know we have some very good return opportunities there. But we'll balance that with our balance sheet and making sure that stays strong and providing returns to shareholders. So it will be a mix and we'll continually look on that -- look at that mix to optimize it moving forward.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And 2 final questions from me. One, Utica. I'm surprised that you'd actually [indiscernible] sequentially different you're no longer tuning anymore well. Just, Greg, as you start seeing the decline over there and what kind of run rate should we assume?
componenttext: And 2 final questions from me. One, Utica. I'm surprised that you'd actually [indiscernible] sequentially different you're no longer tuning anymore well. Just, Greg, as you start seeing the decline over there and what kind of run rate should we assume?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, so on the -- if we look at how we've been able to hold production flat, while we had the drilling break, we brought 14 new wells online in the second quarter and 9 in the first quarter. So you're seeing that really carry over of those wells that we
componenttext: Paul, so on the -- if we look at how we've been able to hold production flat, while we had the drilling break, we brought 14 new wells online in the second quarter and 9 in the first quarter. So you're seeing that really carry over of those wells that we completed in the second quarter, those 5 wells, sorry. So just to be clear again, we brought 14 new wells online in '16, 9 in the first quarter and 5 in the second quarter so you're seeing some carryover there. We anticipate the decline will come and it will probably come in the fourth quarter and first quarter next year as we all start to see that decline.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you continue not going to have any rig over there, what kind of decline rate should we assume?
componenttext: If you continue not going to have any rig over there, what kind of decline rate should we assume?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just take a typical type curve in the Utica and you can predict pretty easily with that decline is going to be, Paul.
componenttext: Just take a typical type curve in the Utica and you can predict pretty easily with that decline is going to be, Paul.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Heikkinen of Heikkinen Energy.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Heikkinen of Heikkinen Energy.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think you're going to get into these details yet, but the first phase of sanction at Liza, how would you describe Phase 1? Or is just too early in your FEED studies as we get into like how the scope and size of the development of [indiscernible] 1
componenttext: I don't think you're going to get into these details yet, but the first phase of sanction at Liza, how would you describe Phase 1? Or is just too early in your FEED studies as we get into like how the scope and size of the development of [indiscernible] 1.4 billion barrels?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think at this point, it's just too early. Obviously, as John said, the reservoir's in the upper end of the range and we're doing all kinds of development studies to try and figure out the most optimal way to begin development of the reservoir. So s
componenttext: Yes, I think at this point, it's just too early. Obviously, as John said, the reservoir's in the upper end of the range and we're doing all kinds of development studies to try and figure out the most optimal way to begin development of the reservoir. So stay tuned, more to come.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then with North Malay coming online next year, can you talk about the annual impact of, from a capital invested and the flip of the amount of cash? I know it's a half year basis, most likely, but what does that to operating cost or just an absolute ca
componenttext: And then with North Malay coming online next year, can you talk about the annual impact of, from a capital invested and the flip of the amount of cash? I know it's a half year basis, most likely, but what does that to operating cost or just an absolute cash generation for the company as that 50% comes online?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So when it comes online in the third quarter, the North Malay Basin field itself will carry very low cash cost. So from a cash cost standpoint, it's going to have a positive impact on our overall portfolio. Now the price is linked to high sulfur fue
componenttext: Sure. So when it comes online in the third quarter, the North Malay Basin field itself will carry very low cash cost. So from a cash cost standpoint, it's going to have a positive impact on our overall portfolio. Now the price is linked to high sulfur fuel oil there and it is only on a month lag so it's going to react to oil prices. And depending on where the oil prices are, we'll -- the amount of cash flow we'll get will increase or decrease depending on what's happening with oil prices. However, we do expect then as that's the third quarter coming in, and then with Stampede coming on in 2018, I think, the broader picture is we're utilizing $700 million of cash right now and not getting any cash flow back. In '18, that flips, so we're getting at least a pickup of $700 million of cash flow from those 2 projects. And again depending on prices, how much excess cash flow we get, we'll see whether we get to 2018. But again, that's why we're always looking and focused on keeping our balance sheet strong through 2017 because in '18, we get this additional cash flow coming into our portfolio.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on the very detailed question, your fourth quarter capitalized interest in G&A, do you have an expectation for that?
componenttext: And just on the very detailed question, your fourth quarter capitalized interest in G&A, do you have an expectation for that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It should be -- it will be the same because our capitalized cost right now is related to the Stampede project. So that will actually continue along until Stampede starts up.
componenttext: It should be -- it will be the same because our capitalized cost right now is related to the Stampede project. So that will actually continue along until Stampede starts up.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey of Wolfe Research.

componenttext: Firstly, just a hopeful one on Guyana. When could we expect first production based on an FID next year?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: I think the best thing to do is refer that to the operator.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's what I -- understand. Could you talk a little bit about firstly your hedging positioning, if there's anything to add there? Secondly, as far as I understand, you're trying to accelerate activity next year, but also maintain a strong balance sheet.
componenttext: That's what I -- understand. Could you talk a little bit about firstly your hedging positioning, if there's anything to add there? Secondly, as far as I understand, you're trying to accelerate activity next year, but also maintain a strong balance sheet. And I assume that would mean spending within cash flows. But are you, therefore, assuming higher oil prices next year? Or how do I kind of square that circle?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the prices, we're assuming and we'll give further definition on that when we announce our budget next year in January, is price is in the current page. Our priority is going to keep the balance sheet strong and our activity levels will reflect keepin
componenttext: Yes, the prices, we're assuming and we'll give further definition on that when we announce our budget next year in January, is price is in the current page. Our priority is going to keep the balance sheet strong and our activity levels will reflect keeping that balance sheet strong. So any further guidance and specifics, we'll give you in January.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Anything on hedging, John?
componenttext: Anything on hedging, John?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So right now, we do not have any hedges outstanding and we'd continue to look at hedges on a regular basis, then we'll assess whether to add them as we have done in the past. Basically, it's insurance to ensure funding of our capital projects. So then, as
componenttext: So right now, we do not have any hedges outstanding and we'd continue to look at hedges on a regular basis, then we'll assess whether to add them as we have done in the past. Basically, it's insurance to ensure funding of our capital projects. So then, as John mentioned, as we look in 2017 and see where prices are, we begin to put more capital back to work or add more drilling rigs in the Bakken. We will be considering adding hedging at that point as insurance.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jeff Campbell from the Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jeff Campbell from the Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question was with regard to the Bakken, an increase to 50 stages and the standard completion line. I'm just wondering, do you just bid in the alteration of your current well spacing assumptions on the heads of some results to be more intensive co
componenttext: My first question was with regard to the Bakken, an increase to 50 stages and the standard completion line. I'm just wondering, do you just bid in the alteration of your current well spacing assumptions on the heads of some results to be more intensive completions?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we don't. Based on the -- on our current reservoir studies with this completion design, we think that's the optimum. Now having said that, we've done a few very close, even closer space pilots and we're waiting on the results, though. So it's too earl
componenttext: No, we don't. Based on the -- on our current reservoir studies with this completion design, we think that's the optimum. Now having said that, we've done a few very close, even closer space pilots and we're waiting on the results, though. So it's too early to speculate one or the other. Right now, we [indiscernible] at  9 and 8 configuration with the 500-foot well spacing with 50-stage fracs appears to be the optimum. As we said though, we're going to continue to push that stage count higher if we can and we just got a successful 60-stage trial in the ground. So very excited about the possibilities there.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just to follow up to make sure I understood that clearly. You have some spacing pilots that are retired and 500 feet with 50 stages being tested. We just don't have the results yet. Is that correct?
componenttext: Okay. Just to follow up to make sure I understood that clearly. You have some spacing pilots that are retired and 500 feet with 50 stages being tested. We just don't have the results yet. Is that correct?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, those are actually lower stage count. But we're monitoring those wells closely to see -- can we see breakthrough. So far, we haven't, but we need a lot more data before we can be definitive.
componenttext: No, those are actually lower stage count. But we're monitoring those wells closely to see -- can we see breakthrough. So far, we haven't, but we need a lot more data before we can be definitive.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that was helpful. I was just wondering, can you update us on the Gulf of Mexico production now and in the next several quarters? And specifically are the valve problems behind you? And what's the production recovery arc?
componenttext: Okay, that was helpful. I was just wondering, can you update us on the Gulf of Mexico production now and in the next several quarters? And specifically are the valve problems behind you? And what's the production recovery arc?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so as we mentioned in our remarks, there's kind of 2 events that are going to happen. The first thing is on Conger, we'll get that defective valve replaced and it will come -- and that will come back online in the first quarter of 2017. As we move to
componenttext: Yes, so as we mentioned in our remarks, there's kind of 2 events that are going to happen. The first thing is on Conger, we'll get that defective valve replaced and it will come -- and that will come back online in the first quarter of 2017. As we move to Tubular Bells, there's 2 events that are going on there -- well actually, 3. First of all, we're going to commence water injection this quarter; secondly, we have a fifth producer that will come online in the first quarter of 2017; and then finally, we'll get that third effective valve replaced in the fourth quarter and the well will come online in the first quarter. And so that's how it kind of lays out in Conger and T-Bells. The rest are pretty much in the we're on a maintain mode run for cash.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I could ask a last 1 real quick. I was just wondering if you can add a little bit color on Skipjack. Was it simply a noncommercial well? Or did it fail to find any kind of hydrocarbons and there wasn't in the system there? And just how the Skipja
componenttext: Okay. If I could ask a last 1 real quick. I was just wondering if you can add a little bit color on Skipjack. Was it simply a noncommercial well? Or did it fail to find any kind of hydrocarbons and there wasn't in the system there? And just how the Skipjack result has affected, if any, in any other exploration targets in the area?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I think what the operators said, the Skipjack well didn't find commercial quantities of hydrocarbons, but it did find the same excellent quality reservoir that we've seen in the Liza well. So how we think about this in the context of the whole bl
componenttext: Okay. So I think what the operators said, the Skipjack well didn't find commercial quantities of hydrocarbons, but it did find the same excellent quality reservoir that we've seen in the Liza well. So how we think about this in the context of the whole block is, again, this is a giant block. It's an 1,150 Gulf of Mexico blocks on the very early stages of the exploration program, and we continue to see numerous additional prospects and play tights on the block. And we haven't even process of those seismic yet, so we still remain very excited about the potential of the block and excited in Skipjack.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Herrlin with Societe Generale.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Herrlin with Societe Generale.

componenttext: Most things have been asked. In the third quarter, you had a $16 [ph] million dry hole costs. Was that all skipped there?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Yes it was, John.

componenttext: Okay. Regarding Payara, however, you want to pronounce it, your next exploration well in Guyana, is it a similar structure, Greg, morphologically? Or is it very deep? Can you talk about it?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Pavel Molchanov of Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Pavel Molchanov of Raymond James.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No one's asked yet about the MLP. The last time you updated the F1 was, I believe, last December, but you're obviously talking about accelerating Bakken activity next year. As that materializes, will you also kind of accelerate, perhaps, the process to wo
componenttext: No one's asked yet about the MLP. The last time you updated the F1 was, I believe, last December, but you're obviously talking about accelerating Bakken activity next year. As that materializes, will you also kind of accelerate, perhaps, the process to work taking the MLB public?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just as a high level, the Midstream business itself is executing well. As you can see from our numbers, the Hawkeye project will kind -- we're working to completion and that will come online in 2017. Market conditions, obviously, are getting better. And a
componenttext: Just as a high level, the Midstream business itself is executing well. As you can see from our numbers, the Hawkeye project will kind -- we're working to completion and that will come online in 2017. Market conditions, obviously, are getting better. And as you mentioned and John has mentioned earlier that we are making our initial preparations on increasing our drilling activity in the Bakken. And I think, when you put all those together we start our increase in drilling there in the Bakken. It does fit nicely into a time line then for the MLP IPO.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. and just kind of conceptually, if and when Hess Midstream ends up becoming a public company, will you limit it to Bakken assets exclusively? Or would you consider adding or broadening its asset base toward other aspects of your domestic midstream po
componenttext: Okay. and just kind of conceptually, if and when Hess Midstream ends up becoming a public company, will you limit it to Bakken assets exclusively? Or would you consider adding or broadening its asset base toward other aspects of your domestic midstream portfolio outside the Bakken?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we'll obviously talk about this as it gets further in the process, but there is no restriction for the midstream to just be in our North Dakota business.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we'll obviously talk about this as it gets further in the process, but there is no restriction for the midstream to just be in our North Dakota business.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Arun Jayaram of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Arun Jayaram of JPMorgan.

componenttext: Just a couple of real quick ones. Assuming the upper end of the resource range at Liza, guys, how many phases would that potentially include? You talked about potential sanctioning Phase I in '17, but how many potential phases could that include?

componenttext: Fair enough, fair enough. And my only other question, Malay comes online in the third quarter. Could you give us a sense of how the ramp could look like in terms of getting the full production there?

componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think again, it will reach plateau to 165 million cubic feet a day. And the fact that we're pre-drilling most of the producers, that should be a pretty steady ramp.
componenttext: Yes, so I think again, it will reach plateau to 165 million cubic feet a day. And the fact that we're pre-drilling most of the producers, that should be a pretty steady ramp.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: At what quarter would you anticipate, I guess, getting this to full production? Is at fourth quarter, first quarter '18?
componenttext: At what quarter would you anticipate, I guess, getting this to full production? Is at fourth quarter, first quarter '18?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll begin ramping in the third quarter, so probably fourth quarter.
componenttext: We'll begin ramping in the third quarter, so probably fourth quarter.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Guy Baber with Simmons.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Guy Baber with Simmons.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The E&P CapEx has been consistently coming in the low guidance pretty much every quarter. Can you guys just discuss the drivers there? To what extent is that activity driven, perhaps offshore versus efficiency captured, deflation capture? Just curious wha
componenttext: The E&P CapEx has been consistently coming in the low guidance pretty much every quarter. Can you guys just discuss the drivers there? To what extent is that activity driven, perhaps offshore versus efficiency captured, deflation capture? Just curious what you're seeing with those savings. And then I have one follow-up.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Just being in a day out right now, we are focused on reducing cost, both in an operating basis as well as capital. So the biggest driver of the reduction in capital -- because we already have the activity reductions basically budgeted in or especial
componenttext: Sure. Just being in a day out right now, we are focused on reducing cost, both in an operating basis as well as capital. So the biggest driver of the reduction in capital -- because we already have the activity reductions basically budgeted in or especially when we updated the forecast guidance. So it really has been efficiencies here and just continuing to look at better ways of doing things and reducing cost from that standpoint.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then the international offshore CapEx, it looks like you basically cut spending to a good portion of your base international offshore assets. Is that something you're comfortable continuing to do through 2017? Or those base assets need to
componenttext: Okay, great. And then the international offshore CapEx, it looks like you basically cut spending to a good portion of your base international offshore assets. Is that something you're comfortable continuing to do through 2017? Or those base assets need to track a bit more capital? And is there anything you'll share about South Arne, for example?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. So as we talk about, we across our portfolio have very good return opportunities both onshore and offshore. But the way we are thinking about allocating capital here as the prices come back and we've mentioned it is we are now initially prepari
componenttext: All right. So as we talk about, we across our portfolio have very good return opportunities both onshore and offshore. But the way we are thinking about allocating capital here as the prices come back and we've mentioned it is we are now initially preparing for increasing capital for the Bakken. So that's going to have our first call in capital will be going to the Bakken. Then again, now as prices continue to move and, as you know, $1 move for us is $70 million of annual cash flow, we'll begin to look across the portfolio. And there are opportunities across our offshore portfolio that we could increase capital to. So it will be something that we will be looking at balancing it with where our balance sheet is and commodity prices are in returns to shareholders, but there's very good returns across our portfolio.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think, the only thing I'd add there is there were logical drilling breaks, both in EG and South Arne associated with processing additional 40 [ph] seismic and ocean bottom seismic. So those were logical, technical drilling breaks, and we're in the p
componenttext: And I think, the only thing I'd add there is there were logical drilling breaks, both in EG and South Arne associated with processing additional 40 [ph] seismic and ocean bottom seismic. So those were logical, technical drilling breaks, and we're in the process of evaluating all that data.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your last question comes from the line of Doug Leggate of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And your last question comes from the line of Doug Leggate of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dig into the fourth quarter production guidance because when I was asking my question, the slides are not yet posted. Can you just walk us through what's driving the drop sequentially? Oil versus gas, prem versus on-prem versus declines? Becau
componenttext: I wanted to dig into the fourth quarter production guidance because when I was asking my question, the slides are not yet posted. Can you just walk us through what's driving the drop sequentially? Oil versus gas, prem versus on-prem versus declines? Because the Bakken seems to be relatively stable and I appreciate that.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So if you're starting with our third quarter, the 314,000 barrels per day, we're going to get an increase of about 11,000 barrels a day combined from JDA and South Arne. As Greg just mentioned in his comments earlier, JDA will get back above 30,000
componenttext: Sure. So if you're starting with our third quarter, the 314,000 barrels per day, we're going to get an increase of about 11,000 barrels a day combined from JDA and South Arne. As Greg just mentioned in his comments earlier, JDA will get back above 30,000 barrels a day because the booster compression tie-in work that we have in the second quarter and South Arne did have a turnaround as well so we're getting a pickup there. That increase, though, is being offset and slightly even more. There's going to be a reduction of about 12,000 barrels a day as it relates to as we talked about Utica. Utica is going to start declining. We're not bringing -- we're not drilling and bringing any wells online there. The Bakken, as you mentioned, still going to come off the 1 0 7 and the decline with the 2 rigs. And in EG, we do have a bit of our normal entitlement change that we have in the fourth quarter as you get through the year of your cost recoveries. So combined, Utica, EG and Bakken will be down about 12,000 barrels a day. And then you have the 1s and 2s across the portfolio again where we're not drilling and that comes to approximately 8,000 barrels a day there just in the Gulf of Mexico, as Greg mentioned. So that's where we get to this approximate of about 305,000 barrels a day in the fourth quarter.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, just to be clear, the Utica is obviously [indiscernible] gas so what is the Utica contribution for that and [indiscernible] in your cash margins, obviously ?
componenttext: So John, just to be clear, the Utica is obviously [indiscernible] gas so what is the Utica contribution for that and [indiscernible] in your cash margins, obviously ?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: About -- I'd say, about 5,000 barrels a day will be of the Utica. It will start declining here significantly with no activity happening in the Utica.
componenttext: About -- I'd say, about 5,000 barrels a day will be of the Utica. It will start declining here significantly with no activity happening in the Utica.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And that is all the time we have for questions today. Thank you very much. This concludes today's conference. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect. Everyone, have a great day.
componenttext: Thank you. And that is all the time we have for questions today. Thank you very much. This concludes today's conference. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect. Everyone, have a great day.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2016 Hess Corporation Conference Call. My name is Nicole, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2016 Hess Corporation Conference Call. My name is Nicole, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Jay Wilson, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nicole. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in our third quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projections
componenttext:
Thank you, Nicole. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in our third quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. 
Today's conference call contains projections and other forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. These statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from those expressed or implied in such statements. These risks include those set forth in the Risk Factors section of Hess's annual and quarterly reports filed with the SEC. 
Also, on today's conference call, we may discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation of the differences between these non-GAAP financial measures and the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures can be found in the supplemental information provided on our website. 
On this morning's call, John Hess will make some high-level comments on the quarter and the progress we are making in executing our strategy. Greg Hill will then review our operations, and John Rielly will discuss our financial results. 
I'll now turn the call over to John Hess.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay, and good morning, everyone. Our company has made important progress in maintaining a strong balance sheet and keeping a tight control on our spending while continuing to invest in future growth, which we believe will create significant val
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay, and good morning, everyone. Our company has made important progress in maintaining a strong balance sheet and keeping a tight control on our spending while continuing to invest in future growth, which we believe will create significant value for our shareholders. Over the course of 2016, we have materially reduced our spending in response to this lower-for-longer oil price environment. We now project our full year 2016 E&P capital and exploratory expenditures to be approximately $2 billion, down $100 million from our previous forecast and more than 50% below 2015. In addition, this month, we will complete a $1.5 billion refinancing of higher-coupon debt, extending our average maturities and lowering our average coupon rate. This transaction further strengthens our balance sheet and liquidity position and defers any significant debt maturities until 2027. 
While we have reduced investment across our producing portfolio, we believe it is very important to continue to fund our growth projects in the Gulf of Thailand, deepwater Gulf of Mexico and offshore Guyana. 
With regard to Guyana, we are very encouraged about the significant resource potential on the 6.6 million acres Stabroek Block. The Liza-3 well was successful, encountering approximately 200 feet of net oil pay and the same high-quality reservoir encountered in the Liza-1 and Liza-2 wells. These result further confirms that Liza is a world-class resource and one of the industry's largest oil discoveries in the last 10 years. With this information, we now expect estimated recoverable resources for Liza to be at the upper end of the previously announced range of 800 million and 1.4 billion barrels of oil equivalent. Predevelopment planning is underway, and we expect to be in a position to sanction the first phase of development in 2017. We believe Liza will offer very attractive economics at current oil prices. 
In addition, we are in the early stages of evaluating the exploration potential on the Stabroek Block. The drilling rig will next move to the Payara prospect located approximately 10 miles northeast from Liza, which with results from this exploration well expected by the time of our next conference call. 
With regard to our 2 other offshore developments, North Malay Basin in the Gulf of Thailand and Stampede in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, are on track to come online in 2017 and 2018, respectively. Together, they will add a combined 35,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in transition from being sizable cash users to significant long-term cash generators for the company. 
Turning to our financial results. In the third quarter of 2016, we posted a net loss of $339 million. On an adjusted basis, the net loss was $340 million or $1.12 per common share compared to an adjusted net loss of $291 million or $1.03 per common share in the year-ago quarter. Compared to the third quarter of 2015, our financial results were negatively impacted by lower crude oil and natural gas sales volumes and selling prices, which more than offset the positive impacts of lower operating costs and DD&A. 
Net production was 314,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day at the upper end of our guidance range for the quarter, while net production from the Bakken exceeded our guidance, averaging 107,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the quarter. Our Bakken team continues to deliver excellent operating results and returns in the core of the play that are competitive with the Permian and Eagle Ford. 
In the third quarter, drilling and completion costs averaged $4.7 million per well, 11% below the year-ago quarter, even as we transition from a 35-stage to a 50-stage completion design. Our high-quality Bakken acreage, industry-leading drilling and completion costs and advantaged infrastructure position our Bakken asset to be a major contributor to the company's future production and cash flow growth. With the recent improvement in oil prices, we are making initial preparations to increase our drilling activity in the play next year. We will provide 2017 guidance, including capital and exploratory expenditures, as usual in January. 
In summary, our company remains well positioned for the current low oil price environment and for a recovery in oil prices. We have one of the strongest balance sheets and long-term growth outlooks among our peers, which we believe will deliver profitable growth and improving returns for our shareholders. 
I will now turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I'd like to provide an operational update and review our progress in executing our strategy. In the third quarter of 2016, we delivered strong operating performance and advanced our offshore developments and exploration activities.  Starti
componenttext:
Thanks, John. I'd like to provide an operational update and review our progress in executing our strategy. In the third quarter of 2016, we delivered strong operating performance and advanced our offshore developments and exploration activities.  
Starting with production. In the third quarter, we averaged 314,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day at the upper end of our guidance range of 310,000 to 315,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, reflecting strong performance across our producing assets. As a result, we reconfirm our full year 2016 production guidance of 315,000 to 325,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, excluding Libya. 
Turning to the Bakken. In the third quarter, production averaged 107,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day compared to 106,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the second quarter and 113,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the year-ago quarter. We drilled 21 wells and brought 22 wells online in the third quarter. For 2016, we now expect to drill approximately 70 wells and bring 100 wells online. This compares to last year when we drilled 182 wells and brought 219 wells online. We currently have 2 rigs operating in the play. But as John mentioned, given the recent improvement in oil prices, we are making preparations to ramp up activity levels next year as prices recover. In the fourth quarter, we expect Bakken production to average between 100,000 and 105,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, reflecting fewer new wells being brought online. For the full year 2016, we expect Bakken production to be approximately 105,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
Over the third quarter, we continued to optimize our completions from our current 50-stage design by successfully completing 53-stage and 57-stage wells, and we are trialing a 60-stage well this quarter. Even with these higher stage count trials, we still reduced our average drilling and completion costs in the third quarter to $4.7 million per well. We expect the 50-stage completion design to yield a 7% uplift in EUR per well in the quarter to play. Wells brought online in the third quarter are expected to deliver growth EUR per well of approximately 830,000 barrels of oil equivalent, and we anticipate this will approach 1 million barrels of oil equivalent in the fourth quarter. 
In the third quarter, average 30-day IP rate from our Middle Bakken wells increased to 899 barrels of oil per day from 811 barrels of oil per day in the second quarter, and we expect to see a further increase in the fourth quarter. 
Moving to the Utica. Net production for the third quarter held at 30,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day compared to 28,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the year-ago quarter and 29,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the second quarter of 2016. 
Now turning to offshore. In the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, net production averaged 61,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the third quarter compared to 54,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the second quarter of 2016. At the Conger field, in which Hess has a 37.5% working interest and is operator, we started a work over to remediate a mechanical failure as announced in our second quarter call and anticipate the well returning to production in the first quarter of 2017. 
At our Tubular Bells Field, in which Hess holds a 57.1% working interest and is operator, we will commence water injection this quarter and are currently completing a fifth producer that we anticipate bringing online in the first quarter of 2017. We will also replace a third defective subsurface valve in the fourth quarter and expect to have the well back online in the first quarter of 2017. As with other fields in the Mississippi Canyon area, Tubular Bells was also shut in for 5 days as a precaution for hurricane activity. 
In Norway, the Aker BP-operated Valhall Field, in which Hess has a 64% interest, continues to perform strongly with net production of 31,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day on average in the third quarter compared to 19,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the second quarter of 2016 and 35,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the year-ago quarter. 
At the Malaysia/Thailand Joint Development Area in the Gulf of Thailand, in which Hess has a 50% interest, the booster compression -- compressor tie-in was successfully completed during a planned shut down. Net production averaged 24,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day compared to 36,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the last year's third quarter, reflecting downtime associated with the compression tie-in and reduced entitlement. In the fourth quarter, we expect net production to be back above 30,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
Moving to developments. At the North Malay Basin in the Gulf of Thailand, in which Hess has a 50% working interest and is operator, we completed installation of the topsides at 3 remote wellhead platforms, which are part of the full field development project. We also completed the drilling of 3 development wells. The project is on schedule for completion in the third quarter of 2017, after which net production is expected to ramp up steadily to 165 million cubic feet per day. 
At the Stampede development project in the Gulf of Mexico, in which Hess holds a 25% working interest and is operator, we successfully lifted and set the topsides deck on the hull. All major lifts are now complete. Drilling operations continued to progress, and first oil remains on schedule for 2018. 
I'd now like to move to Guyana, where Hess has a 30% interest in the 6.6 million acre Stabroek block. On September 5, the operator, ExxonMobil, spud the Liza-3 well located approximately 2.7 miles from the Liza-1 discovery well -- Liza-3 was drilled in 6,000 feet of water and reached a TD of approximately 18,100 feet. The well encountered approximately 200 feet of net oil pay in the same high-quality reservoir encountered during other Liza wells. This reservoir sequence is also confirmed to have a common pressure regime with that of the equivalent reservoir interval found in both Liza-1 and Liza-2. Based on the positive Liza-3 results, we now expect estimated recoverable resources for Liza alone to be at the upper end of ExxonMobil's previously announced range of 0.8 billion and 1.4 billion barrels of oil equivalent. The operator then plans to drill an exploration well at the Payara prospect located approximately 10 miles northeast from Liza with results expected by late January. In parallel, we continue to progress predevelopment activities at Liza and expect to be in a position to sanction the first phase of development in 2017. We remain excited, not only by Liza, which is world class in its own right, but also by the significant further exploration potential of the very large Stabroek Block, which, as a reminder, is the equivalent of approximately 1,150 Gulf of Mexico blocks. 
In closing, I'm very pleased with our team who once again have delivered strong operational performance, relentless continuous improvement and some key milestones and results, which we believe, in combination, will deliver one of the most exciting growth profiles among our large-cap E&P peers over the next decade and beyond. 
I will now turn the call over to John Rielly

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. In my remarks today, I will compare results from the third quarter of 2016 to the second quarter of 2016. The corporation incurred a net loss of $339 million in the third quarter of 2016 compared with a net loss of $392 million in the second
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. In my remarks today, I will compare results from the third quarter of 2016 to the second quarter of 2016. The corporation incurred a net loss of $339 million in the third quarter of 2016 compared with a net loss of $392 million in the second quarter. Excluding items affecting the comparability of earnings between periods, our adjusted net loss was $340 million in the third quarter of 2016 compared with an adjusted net loss of $335 million in the second quarter. 
Turning to E&P. On an adjusted basis, E&P incurred a net loss of $285 million in the third quarter of 2016 compared to a net loss of $271 million in the second quarter of 2016. The changes in the after-tax components of adjusted results for E&P between the third quarter and the second quarter of 2016 were as follows: higher realized selling prices improved results by $3 million; lower sales volumes reduced results by $33 million; lower exploration expenses improved results by $26 million; all other items reduced results by $10 million for an overall increase in third quarter net loss of $14 million. 
In the third quarter, our E&P sales volumes were the same as production volumes, and therefore, the timing of lifting had no impact on our financial results. The E&P effective income tax rate, excluding items affecting comparability, was a benefit of 41% in the third quarter of 2016 compared with a benefit of 47% in the second quarter. 
Turning to Bakken Midstream. Third quarter net income of $13 million increased from $11 million in the second quarter primarily due to lower operating costs and interest expense. EBITDA for the Bakken Midstream before the noncontrolling interest amounted to $73 million in the third quarter of 2016 compared to $68 million in the second quarter. 
Turning to corporate. After-tax corporate and interest expenses were $118 million in the third quarter of 2016 compared to $75 million in the second quarter. The third quarter results include an after-tax charge of $50 million for the premium paid to purchase 65% of our notes due in 2019. 
Turning to cash flow for the third quarter. Net cash provided by operating activities before changes in working capital was $309 million. The net increase in cash resulting from changes in working capital was $23 million. Additions to property, plant and equipment were $529 million. Net borrowings were $731 million. Common and preferred dividends paid were $91 million. All other items resulted in a decrease in cash of $9 million, resulting in a net increase in cash and cash equivalents in the third quarter of $434 million. 
Turning to cash and liquidity. Excluding the Bakken Midstream, we had cash and cash equivalents of $3.5 billion; total liquidity of $8.2 billion, including available committed credit facilities; and total debt of $6.7 billion at September 30, 2016. The increase in debt during the quarter was attributable to the partial completion of a refinancing transaction launched in September to improve the company's liquidity position by purchasing higher-coupon bonds, redeeming near-term maturities and lowering go-forward interest expense. 
To accomplish the refinancing, the corporation issued in September $1 billion of 4.3% notes due in 2027 and $500 million of 5.8% notes due in 2047. The company used $750 million during the third quarter to retire 8.125% notes with a carrying value of $670 million due in 2019. In October, the company will use $625 million to redeem $300 million of notes due in 2017 and to retire notes with a carrying value of $259 million due in 2029 and 2031. As a result of this refinancing, we have no significant debt maturities until 2027. Pro forma for the notes purchased or redeemed in October and excluding the Bakken Midstream, our cash and cash equivalents were $2.9 billion and total debt was $6.1 billion at September 30, 2016. Our pro forma debt-to-capitalization ratio was 24.5%. 
Now turning to guidance. Starting with E&P, cash cost for E&P operations are projected to be in the range of $17.50 to $18.50 per barrel of oil equivalent for the fourth quarter, which includes approximately $2 per barrel for planned workover activity to replace defective subsurface valves at the Conger and Tubular Bells Fields in the Gulf of Mexico. 
Full year cash costs are projected to be in the range of $16 to $16.50 per barrel, which compares to previous full year guidance of $16 to $17 per barrel. DD&A per barrel is forecast to be $26 to $27 per barrel in the fourth quarter and $26.50 to $27 per barrel for the full year, which is down from previous full year guidance of $27 to $28 per barrel. As a result, total E&P unit operating costs are projected to be in the range of $43.50 to $45.50 per barrel in the fourth quarter and $42.50 to $43.50 per barrel for the full year, which is down from previous full year guidance of $43 to $45 per barrel. 
The Bakken Midstream tariff expense is expected to be $4.20 to $4.30 per barrel for the fourth quarter and $3.85 to $3.95 per barrel for the full year, consistent with previous guidance of $3.80 to $4 per barrel. 
Exploration expenses, excluding dry hole costs, are expected to be in the range of $75 million to $85 million in the fourth quarter and $250 million to $260 million for the full year, which is down from previous full year guidance of $260 million to $280 million. 
The E&P effective tax rate is expected to be a deferred tax benefit in the range of 36% to 40% for the fourth quarter and 40% to 44% for the full year of 2016, which compares to previous full year guidance of 41% to 45%. 
Turning to Bakken Midstream. We estimate net income attributable to Hess from the Bakken Midstream segment, which reflects our 50% ownership, to be in the range of $10 million to $15 million in the fourth quarter and $48 million to $53 million for the full year of 2016, which is up from previous full year guidance of $40 million to $50 million. 
Turning to corporate. We expect corporate expenses, net of taxes, to be in the range of $25 million to $30 million for the fourth quarter and $90 million to $95 million for the full year of 2016, which compares to previous full year guidance of $100 million to $110 million. We anticipate interest expense to be in the range of $50 million to $55 million for the fourth quarter and $200 million to $205 million for the full year of 2016. 
This concludes my remarks. We will be happy to answer any questions. I will now turn the call over to the operator.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Doug Terreson of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Doug Terreson of Evercore ISI.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, you've indicated in the past, I think, that sustained Brent prices near $60 would probably be needed for the company to consider a more sort of spending profile. And then this context, some of your peers and semi-peers have taken a little bit of a d
componenttext: John, you've indicated in the past, I think, that sustained Brent prices near $60 would probably be needed for the company to consider a more sort of spending profile. And then this context, some of your peers and semi-peers have taken a little bit of a different tax recently, and they've indicated that even if the oil price does increase that their spending is not going to rise through 2020 with capital returned to shareholders instead and to reduce debt, et cetera. So my question is how you guys are thinking about capital management over the medium term if we have a scenario, whereby the oil price does recover, and whether you feel that the balance between returns on capital and production growth and financial flexibility requires adjustment in relation to the past decade? And if so, how should it change?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Doug, thank you. As you know, our strategy in this lower-for-longer oil price environment has been to preserve our balance sheet, preserve our capability and preserve our growth options, so it's a balance. And we're about value, not volume. But with
componenttext: Well, Doug, thank you. As you know, our strategy in this lower-for-longer oil price environment has been to preserve our balance sheet, preserve our capability and preserve our growth options, so it's a balance. And we're about value, not volume. But with the recent improvement in oil prices, we are making initial preparations to increase activity levels once again in the Bakken next year. We'll provide detailed 2017 guidance, including capital and exploratory expenditures, as usual in January. But we've been stay -- fiscally disciplined. It's a balance sheet that's premier here to fund through the cycle the excellent growth opportunities we have for short cycle in the Bakken and longer cycle in Guyana. And as long as those opportunities offer superior financial returns to our shareholders, that will obviously come into our capital going forward with an eye to keeping the balance sheet in check as well as looking at, over time, offering competitive growth and increasing cash returns to shareholders as well. So it's going to be a balance, and it's going to be a function of oil price.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttext: John, I wonder if I could kick off with a legion news this morning. With the step-out, the 2.7-mile step-out, similar thickness, it looks like. It looks like you've got a really shallow incline on this discovery, I guess. My question is have you hit lowest known oil yet that you find your water contact? And if I may, my understanding is you're staying on the well to deepen the well. Can you talk a little bit about what you're looking for and what the next steps might be?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. This is Greg. Yes. The well is still under evaluation. I mean, what we can say is that we found 200 feet of very nice quality oil sands, consistent with the sands at Liza-1 and Liza-2. So we're going to have to wait until the well is fully eval
componenttext: Yes, Doug. This is Greg. Yes. The well is still under evaluation. I mean, what we can say is that we found 200 feet of very nice quality oil sands, consistent with the sands at Liza-1 and Liza-2. So we're going to have to wait until the well is fully evaluated. Regarding next steps on the well, you're right. We're deepening the well, sidetracking and deepening the well, going through some separate but distinct deeper sand packages.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the real takeaway there, Doug, to your point, Liza has gotten bigger. It's in excess of 1 billion barrels of oil equivalent and we believe offers very attractive financial returns at current prices, and that's the key point.

componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Doug, first of all, we've got to finish the current deepening that we're on with the current well. So we're in operations right now in that well. We've got to finish that out, depending on, obviously, what we find could dictate how long the
componenttext: Well, I think, Doug, first of all, we've got to finish the current deepening that we're on with the current well. So we're in operations right now in that well. We've got to finish that out, depending on, obviously, what we find could dictate how long the well takes to complete. And then we'll move the rig over to Payara and begin drilling at Payara. There, again, depending on what we find will dictate how long it actually takes to finish the well.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Last one for me very quickly. To follow on to Doug's question actually about the Bakken, I understand you're going to give guidance, John, next year. But I'm just curious what your objective is because you're still seeing decline in the field. Are y
componenttext: Okay. Last one for me very quickly. To follow on to Doug's question actually about the Bakken, I understand you're going to give guidance, John, next year. But I'm just curious what your objective is because you're still seeing decline in the field. Are you looking for stability? Are you looking to grow the Bakken next year? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. It's going to be a function of financial returns. We said that until oil prices approach $60, it didn't make sense to accelerate volume for its own sake. But we see where the current improvement in oil prices for next year. But now, we're makin
componenttext: Yes, Doug. It's going to be a function of financial returns. We said that until oil prices approach $60, it didn't make sense to accelerate volume for its own sake. But we see where the current improvement in oil prices for next year. But now, we're making our plans to increase the rig count sum. The exact definition of that, we'll give guidance as we finalize our plans at the end of the year. But the core of the core that we have with the lower drilling and completion costs offer us returns that are competitive with the Permian and the Eagle Ford. So as oil prices have improved, we think it's going to make sense to really take a hard look at increasing our rig count for next year.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's -- on the Bakken, it's more a function of price and value. But obviously, with the improving cost performance that we have as well as the expansion of our stages to 50 stages from 35, all of which we think, as prices improve, will offer very att
componenttext: Yes. It's -- on the Bakken, it's more a function of price and value. But obviously, with the improving cost performance that we have as well as the expansion of our stages to 50 stages from 35, all of which we think, as prices improve, will offer very attractive returns on a short-cycle basis to our shareholders, and so that's why it's being given serious consideration. And finalization of the drilling rig program, we'll give you -- and when we announce our budget for next year in January.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, if I could just add a little more color on what John said. If you look at the well inventory that we have in the Bakken that generates a 15% after-tax or a higher return at $50, that is now over 900 wells. And to put that in context, that's increas
componenttext: Brian, if I could just add a little more color on what John said. If you look at the well inventory that we have in the Bakken that generates a 15% after-tax or a higher return at $50, that is now over 900 wells. And to put that in context, that's increased by some 40% for that same $50 number last year. So as John said, as well costs have come down and our IP rates have gone up as a result of going to higher stage counts, we're sitting on a very high-quality inventory of wells.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think as we said in our opening remarks, the EURs in the fourth quarter will approach 1 million barrels. The EURs in the Middle Bakken in the third quarter were just shy of 900,000 barrels. And well costs continued to drop this quarter. They dro
componenttext: Yes. So I think as we said in our opening remarks, the EURs in the fourth quarter will approach 1 million barrels. The EURs in the Middle Bakken in the third quarter were just shy of 900,000 barrels. And well costs continued to drop this quarter. They dropped from $4.8 million to $4.7 million in spite of the fact that we had a couple higher-stage count trials at 53 and the 57-stage count. So we continue to make those lean manufacturing continuous improvement gains on the wells in spite of increasing -- marginally increasing stage counts.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe one quick one on the Bakken and then a follow-up somewhere else. In the past, you've talked about -- I guess trying to understand the trajectory for 2017 as well. In the past, you've talked about 3 to 4 rigs to maintain production flat in the Bakken
componenttext: Maybe one quick one on the Bakken and then a follow-up somewhere else. In the past, you've talked about -- I guess trying to understand the trajectory for 2017 as well. In the past, you've talked about 3 to 4 rigs to maintain production flat in the Bakken. Is that still the case? Have the improvements you've talked about in terms of lowering costs and productivity improvements changed that at all?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think the 3 to 4 rigs is appropriate. I think we can't say that number has moved closer to 3 than 4, but it's still in between 3 and 4 to hold production flat.
componenttext: No. I think the 3 to 4 rigs is appropriate. I think we can't say that number has moved closer to 3 than 4, but it's still in between 3 and 4 to hold production flat.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if we think about activity, you mentioned in your comments the likelihood of reaching FID in 2017. What are the steps that need to be met between now and then in terms of -- I know it's tough to say at this point in terms of additional appr
componenttext: Okay. And then if we think about activity, you mentioned in your comments the likelihood of reaching FID in 2017. What are the steps that need to be met between now and then in terms of -- I know it's tough to say at this point in terms of additional appraisal wells and activity that needs to be done that we can watch for in terms of hitting FID next year.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think that the biggest thing that needs to be done is really the completion of the FEED work, getting bids back from contractors, all those things and then obviously finalizing your final well designs and locations and all those. So it's just normal
componenttext: No. I think that the biggest thing that needs to be done is really the completion of the FEED work, getting bids back from contractors, all those things and then obviously finalizing your final well designs and locations and all those. So it's just normal project progression to reach the FID point.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think the key point there is, obviously, Liza is a world-class resource in excess of 1 billion barrels of oil equivalent. So we think we're at beyond the commercial threshold already at current prices.
componenttext: And I think the key point there is, obviously, Liza is a world-class resource in excess of 1 billion barrels of oil equivalent. So we think we're at beyond the commercial threshold already at current prices.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Evan Calio of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question on Greg's opening comments, it sounds like the Bakken wells are showing progression and average 30-day IPs as you move to the 50-stage completions. You mentioned the Middle Bakken 30-day IPs you had. What do you see in the lower Three Fo
componenttext: My first question on Greg's opening comments, it sounds like the Bakken wells are showing progression and average 30-day IPs as you move to the 50-stage completions. You mentioned the Middle Bakken 30-day IPs you had. What do you see in the lower Three Forks? And I note that in the context of your off support you just filed that had $843 million in the quarter for all ops wells. So I'm just trying to square the circle from what we're seeing in the third quarter and what we should see or expect in 4Q for that average 30-day IP.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Evan. Really the difference in the numbers I quoted in the third quarter results is the mix of Three Forks wells. So this quarter had a higher proportion at Three Forks wells in it. Those IPs and the Three Forks this quarter were around about
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Evan. Really the difference in the numbers I quoted in the third quarter results is the mix of Three Forks wells. So this quarter had a higher proportion at Three Forks wells in it. Those IPs and the Three Forks this quarter were around about $800 million or so. And we also had an operational issue where we had some production curtailment due to some broad restrictions that adversely impacted some of those Three Forks wells, so it brought the average down on the Three Forks. And that's why we gave you the Middle Bakken numbers. The Middle Bakken numbers were very strong, less impacted by the production and curtailment. So it was that mix that really caused the quarter-on-quarter reduction. But as we said in the fourth quarter, we're going to see, particularly Middle Bakken, EURs approaching that 1 million barrel number in the fourth quarter. So we should have a very strong fourth quarter in terms of EUR on the Bakken.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And do you have an IP estimate for the 4Q kind of total operated? I thought that you were guiding for 900 to 1,000, Is that [indiscernible]
componenttext: Right. And do you have an IP estimate for the 4Q kind of total operated? I thought that you were guiding for 900 to 1,000, Is that [indiscernible]

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We just said that, again, that should approach that 1 million barrels in the fourth quarter IP rate.
componenttext: Yes. We just said that, again, that should approach that 1 million barrels in the fourth quarter IP rate.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great.
componenttext: Great.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, 1,000 barrels a day, 1 million barrel EURs.
componenttext: Sorry, 1,000 barrels a day, 1 million barrel EURs.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, yes. And my second question is there appears to be success with higher proppant loading the Bakken amongst your peers. I know you mentioned higher proppant loadings were less effective in your acreage before yet. What is your current proppant lo
componenttext: Yes, yes, yes. And my second question is there appears to be success with higher proppant loading the Bakken amongst your peers. I know you mentioned higher proppant loadings were less effective in your acreage before yet. What is your current proppant load on that standard 50-stage completion? And are you planning to test any higher loads or kind of test that pieces in line with some other operators in the basin?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Evan, we think that the Bakken is really 2 different areas, right. So in the core of the core, we believe that sticking with sliding-sleeve completions and increasing that stage count as high as you can practically go delivers the highest return.
componenttext: Yes. So Evan, we think that the Bakken is really 2 different areas, right. So in the core of the core, we believe that sticking with sliding-sleeve completions and increasing that stage count as high as you can practically go delivers the highest return. The proppant loading we're using in those areas, again, the core of the core, is anywhere from 80,000 to 110,000 pounds per stage, and that just really depends on where we are because we have the data to kind of say it's better to optimize that between 80,000 and 110,000. Now as should move outside the core, we continue to evaluate other designs, which includes slickwater plug and perf, high-proppant volume completions. And what we ultimately decide there and we'll begin testing some of those techniques, whatever technique gives us the highest return for DSU, that is the one we're going to select. And so the reason for the differences are simply because in the core of the core, you're on the flexure of the structure, so you have an awful high amount of natural fracturing. So you just need less of a proppant load. As you get outside the core, there's less of that effect. So that's what drives these different completion designs outside the core.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Maybe one more, if I could. I know that Hawkeye started up in the 3Q that affected the mix in the quarter. But any color on when that started and ramped up within the quarter just to get a better view of what the forward run rate might look like on
componenttext: Great. Maybe one more, if I could. I know that Hawkeye started up in the 3Q that affected the mix in the quarter. But any color on when that started and ramped up within the quarter just to get a better view of what the forward run rate might look like on a mix -- on a production mix in the Bakken?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you look at the mix, again, the individual well GORs are unchanged. And so nothing is going on in the field from a GOR level. What has changed, though, overall mix of production as we bring more wells, gas and NGLs, as we bring more of that into t
componenttext: Yes. If you look at the mix, again, the individual well GORs are unchanged. And so nothing is going on in the field from a GOR level. What has changed, though, overall mix of production as we bring more wells, gas and NGLs, as we bring more of that into the plant. So previously, flared volumes were gathering additional previously flared volumes and putting those into the plant. So that's what's really going on with our mix.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Was that -- when in the quarter was the start-up?
componenttext: Was that -- when in the quarter was the start-up?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: For now, Hawkeye is coming in on phases, right? So it will be completed in 2017. And it really -- I wouldn't say anything in particular with Hawkeye itself. It is, as Greg said, we are just continuing to hook up more and more of our pads, where either the
componenttext: For now, Hawkeye is coming in on phases, right? So it will be completed in 2017. And it really -- I wouldn't say anything in particular with Hawkeye itself. It is, as Greg said, we are just continuing to hook up more and more of our pads, where either they were previously flared and just hooking up to our own infrastructure. And we even have small amounts that we hook up to other infrastructure as well, the third-party infrastructure. And that additional gathering is what is causing the gas rate and the NGL volumes to go up and just causing pure math on the percentages of crude. But as Greg said, there is no change of the mix at the wellhead.
